reflections.self_assessment: I played consistently pro-mission and helped establish early trust on Mission 1, but I didn’t push hard enough to dissect vote patterns and mission team compositions after the first fail. I should have been more vocal about locking in likely goods, challenging the inclusion of repeat suspicious players, and coordinating more clearly with people who seemed like they might be Merlin or Percival.

player_observations.Bob: You were subtly directive, often nudging team choices without over-explaining, which fits a careful Merlin style, though it was hard to distinguish you from an informed evil or a confident good early on. Your quiet consistency on team logic in later missions, especially around excluding certain people, should have been a stronger signal to me.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a very believable, middle-of-the-pack good, blending in by supporting reasonable teams while slipping onto a critical failing mission without drawing big suspicion. Your willingness to be on the larger Mission 2 team and then not over-defend yourself afterward was an effective low-heat evil strategy.
player_observations.Diana: You leaned into a confident, analytical persona that made your presence on Mission 3 feel initially reasonable, even when it turned out to be disastrous with two fails. The way you framed suspicions on others instead of addressing the implications of that mission outcome was a strong assassin-style misdirection that I should’ve challenged more.
player_observations.Eve: Your play felt somewhat disconnected from the emerging table consensus, which in hindsight fits Oberon’s information disadvantage—sometimes your team proposals and pushes felt slightly off without being blatantly evil. Leading the final failing mission while not seeming like the central strategist for evil was an effective way to fly under the radar.
player_observations.Frank: You projected a very Merlin-like or strong-information-good vibe, confidently steering suspicion and speaking with authority about who was likely clean or dirty. That resemblance to a power good role made it very hard to read you correctly and likely helped mislead us away from the real Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as straightforwardly good, especially from the early successful mission, but didn’t strongly impose your views on later team compositions. Your relatively low-aggression, cooperative play made you seem trustworthy, though I wish we had more strongly consolidated around you as a confirmed-lean-good later.
player_observations.Henry: You seemed to be trying to track information carefully and sometimes reacted strongly to small shifts in team composition, which in hindsight fits Percival trying to interpret signals from suspected Merlin/Morgana. Your reads didn’t gain as much traction as they could have, and I should have paid closer attention when your instincts diverged from the popular narrative.
player_observations.Iris: You played a quieter, more reactive good, tending to follow arguments rather than initiate them, which made it harder to form a clear read on you but also kept you from being heavily targeted by suspicion. Your voting pattern felt mostly consistent with good, but I didn’t work with you enough to build a strong mutual trust.
player_observations.Jack: You appeared flexible and willing to go along with reasonable-sounding proposals, which made you seem like a cooperative good rather than someone pushing a hidden agenda. Because you didn’t anchor big accusations or hard defenses, your alignment stayed a bit blurry, and I didn’t leverage your perspective as much as I could have.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed low-key enough that I didn’t draw much heat, which helped evil avoid being cleanly solved, especially around the chaos of Missions 2 and 3. I could have done a better job subtly influencing team compositions and discussion tempo so that my presence more actively misdirected good rather than just blending into the background.

player_observations.Bob: Played aggressively and leaned into high-impact mission choices, which fit an assassin trying to stay relevant in late-game reads. His involvement on the double-fail Mission 3 created good WIFOM and made it hard to cleanly clear or condemn him.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and somewhat trusting, especially early, which made them a natural candidate for inclusion on teams. Their generally honest table presence helped evil slip into teams without too much resistance.
player_observations.Diana: Tried to reason things out systematically and pushed for ‘sensible’ team constructions, which signaled a good-aligned mindset but also made her vulnerable to being subtly steered. Her leadership on Mission 2 showed she was willing to compromise to keep consensus, which evil could exploit.
player_observations.Eve: Played a strong, proactive evil game by getting on key missions and using the Mordred information edge to pressure good. Her participation in the failed missions helped frame suspicion in multiple directions rather than squarely on herself.
player_observations.Frank: Approached the game with a logical tone but seemed a bit cautious, especially in leadership situations. His Mission 4 team showed he was trying to assemble a ‘clean’ group, but that caution came too late to undo earlier damage.
player_observations.Grace: Came off as very naturally good and was often treated as a stable core pick early, which ironically helped evil hide among the people orbiting her. She didn’t push super hard on alternative narratives, which let some suspicious patterns persist.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a careful information-holder, trying not to overextend, which fit Merlin but also meant some of his soft clears and pushes were easy to muddy. His reluctance to go all-in on certain accusations gave evil room to survive deeper into the game.
player_observations.Iris: Seemed actively engaged in reading table dynamics and was quick to track who was defending whom, consistent with a Percival trying to protect possible Merlins. However, her protective instincts didn’t fully lock onto the right signals, which left Henry less shielded than ideal.
player_observations.Jack: Adopted a confident, occasionally misleading tone that worked well for Morgana, sending mixed signals to Percival and complicating Merlin’s cover. His presence in discussions created plausible ‘wise good’ energy that helped divert attention from the true information sources.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted the initial Mission 1 team and stayed reasonably open-minded, but I didn’t adjust strongly enough after Mission 2 failed under my leadership. I need to be more aggressive about excluding overlapping suspects from subsequent teams and paying closer attention to vote patterns and who quietly benefits from each mission result.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, low-key Merlin game, avoiding big pushes and instead gently steering teams, which made him hard to read as special but also harder for good to follow confidently.
player_observations.Charlie: Seemed genuinely confused at key points, which made them look honest but also a bit passive; they didn’t strongly drive alternative team proposals when there was evidence to pivot.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed very under-the-radar as Oberon, not drawing much attention to themselves at all; their presence didn’t factor heavily into most team discussions, which ultimately helped evil stay hidden.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, maintained a solid, composed table presence, rarely overreaching; they let others argue and subtly backed lines of reasoning that pointed suspicion away from the actual Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, tried to protect Merlin by not over-clearing anyone too loudly, but that restraint also meant town didn’t get as much benefit from his extra information as it could have.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good player—open and talkative—but occasionally accepted risky team compositions without pushing hard to resolve contradictions from earlier missions.
player_observations.Henry: Mordred played a very persuasive, central role in team-building, confidently inserting himself onto multiple teams and using the partial successes and failures to muddy reads rather than draw clean conclusions.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, did a good job mirroring the tone of a thoughtful good player, chiming in with plausible logic and avoiding obviously opportunistic votes, which made her blend in well with the village.
player_observations.Jack: Looked very trustworthy early due to the clean Mission 1, and then leaned on that credit for later discussions; he didn’t pivot hard enough once later missions failed, which unintentionally helped evil hide among the more active talkers.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that the fails on Missions 2–4 pointed strongly to Grace, Iris, and Henry being evil, but I didn’t communicate those suspicions subtly enough through my team votes and advocacy. I also failed to clearly champion consistently good-leaning players like Bob and Jack early, which made it harder for good to converge on safe teams without exposing myself as Merlin.

player_observations.Bob: Played very straightforwardly and voted in a way that generally aligned with good interests, but didn’t press his reads aggressively enough to shift table consensus.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as very naturally good and trustworthy, but also seemed somewhat deferential in team discussions, which limited his impact on steering away from bad teams.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively under the radar as assassin, not drawing much suspicion and letting others (especially Grace and Iris) take the spotlight in mission shaping and social dynamics.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, seemed uncertain about distinguishing Merlin from Morgana and didn’t strongly anchor onto a single candidate, which reduced the protective effect Percival can offer.
player_observations.Frank: Looked solidly good and was trusted early, but after Mission 2’s fail didn’t push hard to dissect who was likely responsible, leaving the narrative space open for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, projected a confident, central leadership style, especially early, and used that to get onto critical teams while maintaining a plausible good persona after the first success.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, contributed to confusion largely through unpredictable voting and team reactions, making it harder for good to form consistent alignment reads on him.
player_observations.Iris: Played a very convincing Morgana, mirroring a ‘Merlin-like’ confidence in reads and team advocacy, which likely contributed to misdirection around who had real information.
player_observations.Jack: Showed strong good instincts and was willing to question suspect teams, but joined the final failed mission, suggesting he either overtrusted others’ reads or was swayed late in discussion.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted as Mordred, getting on early teams and helping secure key fails without drawing too much suspicion, which let evil control missions 2–4. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around who was suspicious to misdirect Merlin and Percival earlier, instead of relying mainly on quiet reliability.

player_observations.Bob: Leaned into the hidden-threat role well on mission 2, but could sometimes over-participate in accusations, which risked connecting them to other evil players.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very chaotic and hard-to-read game consistent with Oberon, creating background noise that made information harder for good to parse but also harder for evil to coordinate around.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to trust early teams and seemed to rely more on social reads than mechanical logic, which made her a bit easier to keep on misfiring or mixed teams.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and seemed hesitant to hard-push suspicions, which made her appear generally reasonable but also less influential in redirecting teams away from evil.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and honest, especially after the clean first mission, which made him a useful ‘clear’ good in table talk that evil could subtly nudge without much pushback.
player_observations.Grace: Her team selections and mission reactions were generally sharp and aligned with hidden information, which made her look like Merlin; she was careful but not quite cautious enough in concealing how accurate her reads were.
player_observations.Henry: As a leader on mission 2, his team choice was somewhat loose, which allowed multiple evil to slip in; overall his decision-making felt more trusting than deductive.
player_observations.Iris: Showed signs of trying to protect and infer Merlin, tracking patterns in Grace’s behavior, but occasionally second-guessed herself and didn’t press her strongest reads hard enough.
player_observations.Jack: Balanced aggression and subtlety well as Assassin, taking in social cues and mission outcomes to narrow Merlin candidates, and was willing to assemble a risky mission 4 that still worked out for evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively hidden as evil while letting Eve, Frank, and Jack take most of the visible risk, which helped us reach three failed missions without drawing heavy suspicion specifically onto me. I could have been more proactive in steering team compositions earlier, especially around Missions 3 and 4, to better frame specific good players and make Merlin-hunting at the end even easier.

player_observations.Bob: Tended to play cautiously and accept fairly consensus-driven teams, which made him look reliably good but not especially influential in shaping the table’s reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Early willingness to go on and support Mission 1 without drama made them read very town-core, but later they didn’t press hard enough on re-evaluating players after the Mission 2 fail.
player_observations.Diana: As an early leader, built a team that looked reasonable but which backfired with the double fail; afterwards, seemed somewhat reactive rather than driving a clear narrative about who was evil.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive evil game, comfortably sitting on high-impact teams and taking fails at key moments without becoming the automatic scapegoat, which gave the rest of us cover.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, still managed to blend in and participate on critical missions, taking a fail at an important point in a way that didn’t immediately out them, which is tricky from an information-disconnected role.
player_observations.Grace: Generally approached teams with a logical, deduction-oriented mindset; as leader on Mission 5, seemed to be trying to thread a careful needle but ended up trusting the wrong mix of players.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, seemed to narrow in on a Merlin candidate but didn’t strongly broadcast or coordinate that information in a way that clearly guided team selection late game.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, did a good job not being blatantly obvious, but their quiet correctness on some reads made them subtly central; with slightly more aggression from evil on the social side, they might have been framed more convincingly.
player_observations.Jack: Played Mordred as a low-heat but consistently included option for teams, leveraging the hidden-from-Merlin aspect well and helping ensure that late-game trust skewed in evil’s favor.

reflections.self_assessment: I was consistently included on teams and helped build trust by never failing missions, but I didn’t push hard enough to challenge some of the more dangerous assumptions about who was evil, especially around Grace and Bob. I also failed to protect Merlin well enough during discussion, not doing enough to create plausible alternative reads that could have drawn the Assassin away from Charlie.

player_observations.Bob: You played a very convincing good player, leveraging early trust from Mission 1 to stay largely above suspicion. Your calm presence on the successful large Mission 4 team made it harder to separate you from the actually good players.
player_observations.Charlie: You were a very effective Merlin, guiding teams toward mostly safe compositions and avoiding obvious, loud pushes that would give you away. However, your accuracy and subtle consistency still left enough of a trail for the Assassin to lock onto you by the end.
player_observations.Diana: You stayed relatively low profile as Oberon, which made it harder for good to get strong alignment reads on you either way. Your lack of strong stances helped keep attention focused on louder or more central players.
player_observations.Eve: You navigated the game well as Assassin, paying close attention to patterns in approvals and Charlie’s influence to land the correct shot. Your social positioning didn’t draw much suspicion, which gave you room to observe and analyze Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Frank: You felt like a quieter but generally reasonable good presence, adding to team legitimacy without dominating the conversation. Your lack of extreme reads made it harder to use you as a clear reference point for alignment.
player_observations.Grace: You played Mordred in a way that blended in with good discussion, especially around the failed Mission 2 where suspicion didn’t lock firmly onto you. Your ability to participate constructively without overreaching kept your name from becoming a consensus evil target.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you did a decent job of treating both Charlie and Bob as plausible information sources without making it obvious whom you trusted more. At times, it felt like you could have been more forceful in steering teams once you formed a stronger Merlin read.
player_observations.Iris: You came across as straightforward and trustworthy, which helped good stabilize after the fail on Mission 2. Your presence on multiple successful teams reinforced that image and made you a low-priority suspect for most of the game.
player_observations.Jack: You were somewhat on the periphery of the core mission decisions, which made your alignment harder to pin down but also limited your impact on team compositions. Your lower engagement meant you were rarely a focal point of suspicion or trust, keeping you neutral in the overall dynamic.

reflections.self_assessment: I over-relied on mission results instead of pushing harder on vote patterns and cross-checking them with table talk, which let a fairly clear evil cluster (Bob/Grace/Jack) slip through too long. I did reasonably well trusting Charlie and Henry, but I should have been more vocal in defending Diana and questioning Grace’s leadership choices after Mission 2.

player_observations.Bob: Very comfortable sitting in the middle of teams and blending in; his willingness to go on multiple key missions without pushing for loud reads made him hard to flag as Mordred.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a straightforward, consistent good style—his reactions to fails felt genuinely process-oriented, which made him a solid anchor for good, even if he didn’t hard-push on suspects.
player_observations.Diana: Her reads were subtly accurate but not forceful enough to override group momentum; classic Merlin style of nudging rather than dictating, which unfortunately let evil keep plausible deniability.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t strongly shape team compositions, which is effective Oberon play but made it hard for good to get alignment info from her behavior.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed genuinely torn between potential Merlins, which showed in somewhat cautious voting; he tried to protect his suspected Merlin but didn’t push that read aggressively.
player_observations.Grace: Led assertively and framed herself as a problem-solver after Mission 1, which helped her credibility; her controlled demeanor on critical missions was very assassin-like in hindsight.
player_observations.Henry: His decision-making on teams felt sincere and mostly aligned with good interests, but he didn’t fully capitalize on the information from Mission 3’s fail to narrow down evil.
player_observations.Iris: Showed willingness to take risks in team-building, but her Mission 4 leadership didn’t sufficiently lock out previously suspicious players, which inadvertently helped evil secure the game.
player_observations.Jack: Played a convincing social game as Morgana, using confident takes and light pressure to look like a power good role; he benefited a lot from Percival’s uncertainty and the general trust he generated.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful early teams and used that to anchor my reads, which helped me trust Henry and Frank more than average. I could have been more vocal in challenging the Mission 3 team composition after the double fail, especially by pushing harder on the Henry/Charlie/Iris triangle. In future games, I should communicate my suspicions more assertively so good coordination is clearer to Merlin and Percival.

player_observations.Bob: Played a careful info-gathering game and avoided over-asserting, which fit well with a cautious Percival style but sometimes made his Merlin read less obvious to the rest of good.
player_observations.Charlie: Comfortably accepted core-team status early, then used that trust to slip onto the doomed Mission 3, showing a preference for striking later rather than sabotaging early to avoid suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Blended into early good teams smoothly and let others drive team discussions, a low-profile Morgana approach that helped keep attention off her until after the critical missions.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed off the contentious Mission 3 and supported stable, low-drama team choices, which made her look reliably good and helped stabilize Mission 4.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very subtle Merlin, guiding team choices without making hard proclamations, which protected his identity enough that the assassin missed him in the end.
player_observations.Grace: Used the power of first leadership to put together a safe-looking Mission 1, gaining early trust as Mordred and avoiding the typical early-evil overreach.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforward and cooperative, and his presence on multiple successful missions reinforced a naturally trustworthy table image that ultimately drew the assassin’s shot.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, created confusion by joining the failing Mission 3 in a way that muddied alignment reads and made it harder for good to pinpoint which of the three was evil.
player_observations.Jack: Led a clean and decisive Mission 4, favoring a conservative team anchored around previously successful players, which helped close out the game solidly for good.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly leaned toward Bob as Merlin fairly early and used my votes and table talk to subtly support his reads without making the connection too obvious, especially in the later missions. I could improve by being more vocal in framing alternative evil worlds around Henry and Eve earlier, and by better managing how strongly I publicly townread Iris so that the assassin had fewer plausible Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Bob: Very controlled Merlin play: you pushed key good teams (especially M4/M5) without overexplaining, and your hesitation around the M2 group was a strong but well-veiled signal.
player_observations.Charlie: Solid, low-drama good play: you felt genuinely confused after M2, which made your later votes and reactions quite trustworthy as alignment indicators.
player_observations.Diana: You played a calm, steady good game and slotted into the M4/M5 teams without trying to over-direct, which helped keep those teams from looking suspiciously ‘too perfect.’
player_observations.Eve: Your early Mission 1 success made you look very safe, and you leveraged that well going into M2, though triple-failing there ended up overexposing the evil team composition.
player_observations.Frank: As assassin, you stayed reasonably believable after being on a clean M1, but your endgame Merlin guess on Iris showed you were still misreading the subtle distinction between her genuine-good uncertainty and Bob’s more guided information.
player_observations.Grace: Your Oberon play was fairly chaotic and hard to read; the lack of clear coordination made you look strange, but also kept you from obviously grouping with the other evils.
player_observations.Henry: You played a convincing information role as Morgana, especially around M3, but your involvement in a failed mission plus your positioning afterward made you a more likely evil candidate late.
player_observations.Iris: You had very natural, inquisitive good-player vibes and asked the kind of questions that made you look like you were still solving, which both stabilized trust in the later missions and accidentally drew the assassin’s shot.
player_observations.Jack: You were a stabilizing presence in the late game, willing to repeat a previously clean team and not overcomplicate the logic, which helped lock in the final two successes.

reflections.self_assessment: I identified most of the evil players fairly early, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for good to follow without exposing myself. I also failed to build a strong, consistent circle of trust around Henry and the cleared goods, which let evil control later team compositions and eventually secure the win.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and generally read as good, but didn’t push hard enough on the information from early missions to challenge suspicious team proposals.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as a flexible, mid-assertive voice and used the fail on Mission 2 to create ambiguity rather than drawing heat onto himself.
player_observations.Diana: Took calculated risks, especially on Mission 3 with the double fail, and managed to stay just barely within the realm of ‘overzealous good’ instead of clearly evil.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively quiet and off-tempo with the rest of the table, which actually fit Oberon well and made it harder for good to use social cohesion as a read.
player_observations.Frank: Projected strong confidence in their reads and used that authority to steer suspicion away from themselves and other evils at key points.
player_observations.Grace: Generally consistent and sincere-seeming, but a bit passive, which made it hard for others to strongly town-read her despite being on the successful first mission.
player_observations.Henry: Behaved like a typical cautious information-role good, but didn’t leverage that image to force more disciplined team selection as the game progressed.
player_observations.Iris: Followed table consensus more than driving it, which kept them safe from suspicion but limited their impact on correcting wrong narratives.
player_observations.Jack: Showed flashes of good deduction but didn’t lock in on a consistent theory, making it easier for evil to exploit shifting suspicions and uncertain voting.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the other visible evil roles by leaning into suspicion on multiple good candidates, which helped keep Merlin (Henry) from feeling completely 'obvious' and preserved ambiguity for the assassination. I could improve by building a clearer, more consistent townie narrative earlier so that, if the game had gone to a closer Merlin guess, my reads would have looked more organic and less opportunistic.

player_observations.Alice: As Oberon, Alice played quietly and blended into the background, which made her alignment hard to read and kept her from drawing targeted scrutiny or trust—effectively neutral but non-damaging to evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s play was straightforwardly good-leaning: team selections and voting patterns were generally consistent with a genuine attempt to solve, which made him feel like a ‘baseline’ good player for comparison.
player_observations.Diana: Diana showed a cautious, methodical style, often avoiding hard accusations and instead focusing on incremental information from each mission, which made her look reasonably trustworthy but not loudly influential.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, Eve did well mixing in with good by taking reasonable mission stances and getting on a failing mission without becoming the clear scapegoat, showing a good balance between pushing outcomes and preserving her image.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played like a classic good player: transparent in reasoning and relatively consistent in logic, but occasionally a bit predictable, which made him easier to pocket or use as a reference point.
player_observations.Grace: Grace appeared very team-oriented and collaborative, often deferring slightly to others’ reasoning while still providing input; this made her feel supportive but not like a primary driver of deductions, which kept her from being heavily suspected as evil.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, Henry was subtly but consistently on the right side of key evil reads, yet tried to dilute those reads among multiple suspects; the balance was decent, but his pattern of being ‘coincidentally correct’ often enough still left traces to follow.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, Iris clearly tried to protect perceived Merlin candidates by amplifying certain ‘trustworthy’ voices, but at times that protection was a bit transparent, which risked indirectly signaling who she thought was Merlin.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, Jack leaned into the ‘loud good’ role convincingly, pushing strong opinions and creating a plausible Merlin-like presence, which contributed to the confusion around true information sources and helped muddy the Merlin read.

reflections.self_assessment: I had a decent read on who was evil by mid-game, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for my team to act on it without exposing myself. I also could have done more to influence team selections and voting patterns earlier, especially around Missions 2 and 3, where better resistance could have changed momentum.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and felt generally trustworthy; her inclusion on the first failed team ended up making her look suspicious despite being good, and she didn’t strongly push back with alternative reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Took initiative as a leader and tried to build logical teams, but seemed a bit too trusting, especially after Mission 2’s fail, not pressing hard enough on the likely sources of evil.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed low-impact and under the radar, which is very effective for Oberon; her lack of strong pushing or defending kept her off most people’s suspicion lists.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was solid and patient, letting others drive the narrative; she stayed just active enough in discussion to appear engaged without drawing strong Merlin suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed uncertain about who Merlin was and didn’t strongly shield any particular player, which made it easier for evil to narrow down the real Merlin late game.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good player with mostly consistent logic, but didn’t push aggressively enough to overturn questionable team choices when the game started tilting evil.
player_observations.Henry: Mordred was very effective at blending in; he leveraged leadership on Mission 4 well, assembling a team that looked reasonably balanced while still securing a decisive fail.
player_observations.Iris: Morgana presence was strong; she projected a kind of controlled confidence that plausibly signaled Merlin, which likely contributed to confusion for Percival and the rest of good.
player_observations.Jack: Came across as very genuinely good and was generally trusted; his early successful mission helped his image, but he didn’t convert that trust into strong resistance against later bad teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably flexible in my reads and didn’t hard-tunnel on any one narrative too early, which helped me stay open to alternate theories. However, I clearly didn’t push hard enough on resolving the contradictions between mission results and table talk, and I should have been more vocal and structured in arguing for or against specific team comps.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very cautious, information-protective Merlin, often avoiding strong public accusations, which made her look like a quiet but thoughtful good player rather than a clear seer.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and consistent, generally supporting teams that looked reasonable from a good perspective, which made him seem reliably villager-aligned.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, blended in well by not over-pushing any single narrative and keeping her tone measured, which made her look like a balanced, rational good player rather than a scheming evil role.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, seemed to hedge between Merlin candidates, sometimes signal-boosting subtle reads but not forcefully steering the table, which made her look like a cautious but genuinely invested good role.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a classic solid good: supported sensible early teams, didn’t overreact to one failed mission, and kept a low-ego, cooperative presence that made him easy to trust.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, did a strong job of looking like core-good early by being included in multiple teams and not pushing overly aggressive agendas, leveraging that early trust throughout the game.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his play felt a bit disjointed and harder to read, with some choices that seemed off from a coordinated evil plan, which ironically made him look more like a confused good player.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, projected confident and reasoned takes that mimicked a power-good role, especially around team discussions, making her a very plausible Merlin candidate from the outside.
player_observations.Jack: Approached leadership pragmatically, building teams that were defensible given available info, and didn’t appear to be driving any hidden agenda, which strongly signaled a good alignment.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team by getting on the critical Mission 2 fail and staying relatively unsuspicious afterward, letting Mordred and Assassin do a lot of the heavy lifting later. I could have done more active misdirection around Merlin/Perci reads, especially by pushing harder on alternative Merlin candidates once Grace started to look accurate.

player_observations.Alice: Played an effective, low-key Mordred, getting on multiple mission teams and helping secure early and mid-game fails without drawing overwhelming suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, their signals were harder to read, but they still created enough general confusion to keep good from forming a clean consensus.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to project a fairly straightforward good vibe and was trusted enough to be repeatedly included on teams, which unfortunately put her on several failing missions.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and seemed to lean heavily on mission results for reads, which made it harder for her to isolate the hidden evil roles despite being often included.
player_observations.Frank: Looked convincingly good early, especially after the first successful mission, but didn’t manage to convert that into strong late-game leadership or a tight circle of trust.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, she read the board well overall but couldn’t translate her information into strong enough pushes to get consistently safe teams or avoid the Assassin’s endgame shot.
player_observations.Henry: As a leader on Mission 2, he put together a risky team that included multiple evils, and afterward didn’t strongly drive a clear narrative about who should be trusted.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, her protection of Merlin was only partially effective; she had some right instincts but didn’t commit firmly enough to a strong Merlin cover story.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, he benefited from the general confusion and correctly trusted the evil information enough in the endgame to secure the win with the final shot.

reflections.self_assessment: I focused on reading voting patterns and mission outcomes, which helped me correctly distrust some of the later mission team compositions. However, I didn’t push hard enough for alternative teams on Missions 4 and 5 or clearly communicate a cohesive theory of who was evil, which let evil coordinate and slip through.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana very subtly, using the early Mission 2 fail to sow confusion without becoming the obvious suspect. She blended into the good-team discussions well and avoided taking loud stances that could backfire.
player_observations.Charlie: Consistently appeared reasonable and cooperative, which matched their actual good alignment. Their arguments tended to be cautious rather than forceful, which may have limited their influence when it mattered most.
player_observations.Diana: Was involved in the early failing mission but didn’t come off as strongly suspicious afterward, suggesting a calm and measured table presence. Often framed things in terms of team-wide logic rather than personal reads.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, maintained a low-to-mid profile while steering just enough suspicion away from the real evil cluster. Their presence on the clean Mission 1 and then distance from obvious blame helped keep them trusted long enough.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, their voting and team preferences sometimes felt off-tempo with the table, which created a bit of noisy suspicion. However, that inconsistency also helped obscure the larger evil structure and confused good’s deductions.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good player, building arguments from mission data and generally supporting logical team choices. Their leadership on Mission 5 was decisive but unfortunately relied on a read that included too many hidden evil roles.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, Henry seemed to be juggling conflicting Merlin/Morgana signals and didn’t over-commit publicly to a single narrative. Their caution reduced the risk of outing Merlin directly, but it also meant good lacked a strong guiding voice.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, Iris stayed relatively subtle, not pushing too aggressively on any single player, which helped keep their role hidden. They tried to nudge suspicions in the right direction, but their soft influence wasn’t quite enough to overcome the late-game evil coordination.
player_observations.Jack: As Mordred, Jack stayed under the radar well, avoiding becoming a focal point of accusations despite being on the final failing team. Their style leaned toward quiet agreement and incremental steering rather than bold, attention-grabbing moves.

reflections.self_assessment: I leaned into my Morgana identity effectively by staying relatively quiet and letting Charlie’s subtle guidance stand out as Merlin, which helped the assassin lock onto him in the end. I could improve by being more active in mission discussions to sow targeted doubt around specific players, rather than mostly benefiting passively from others’ reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently pro-mission and projected a solidly good vibe, which made her an easy include on teams and a stable anchor for good without drawing suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Guided team selections in a careful, low-key way that fit Merlin well—strong reads without being too loud—but was just visible enough in the patterns of success/fail that evil could zero in on him.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed under the radar as Oberon, blending in with the general table noise; their low profile meant they didn’t strongly sway team choices but also avoided becoming a focus of suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: Handled the assassin role decisively, reading the information flow around the mission outcomes and discussion tempo well enough to correctly identify Merlin in the endgame.
player_observations.Frank: Had a quieter, supportive presence, generally following emerging consensus; this made them look reasonably trustworthy but not central to strategic direction.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, did a good job hiding in plain sight—joining the failed mission while remaining plausible—using a balanced, logical tone that didn’t scream evil even when near the action.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, clearly tried to interpret the Merlin/Morgana signals, but their reads occasionally wavered, which created some ambiguity that ultimately helped evil keep Charlie exposed.
player_observations.Iris: Came across as straightforward and mission-focused, contributing to her being repeatedly selected; her apparent sincerity helped stabilize good teams but also gave evil cover on mixed groups.
player_observations.Jack: Had minimal direct impact on final team compositions but played like a cautious good: asking reasonable questions, not overcommitting to bold accusations, and generally avoiding extremes.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by choosing when to pass and when to fail missions, helping keep suspicion spread out while still securing the win. I could improve by more actively shaping table talk and suspicion narratives instead of mostly relying on quiet reliability and mission choices to appear good.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and tended to follow emerging table consensus, which made her seem reliably good but not strongly influential in team selection debates.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as steady and logical, often anchoring reasoning around mission results, which made him feel like a trustworthy reference point for many players.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she pushed subtly rather than forcefully, guiding teams without drawing too much heat, though her consistent presence on good teams hinted at her hidden information.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively low-profile as Oberon, which reduced coordination with the rest of evil but also kept them from attracting targeted suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he actively tried to read the Merlin/Morgana pairing, but his leadership on Mission 1 (which failed) put him in a tricky credibility spot early.
player_observations.Grace: Balanced aggression and restraint well as the Assassin, remaining just suspicious enough to avoid being fully trusted while still having decent reads for an endgame shot.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very straightforward good style, using mission outcomes to drive his logic, but his Mission 3 leadership ending in a fail likely hurt his perceived reliability.
player_observations.Iris: Showed willingness to take risks with team compositions, and the failed Mission 4 under her leadership created strong, but somewhat scattered, late-game blame dynamics.
player_observations.Jack: Leaned into the deceptive potential of Morgana, often aligning with plausible good logic while being flexible enough to pivot suspicions as mission results came in.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly focused early trust on Frank while staying flexible about Diana vs Frank as Merlin/Morgana, and I tried to keep my Merlin read somewhat subtle going into the final mission. I could have pushed harder to expose the double-fail patterns from Mission 3 and more explicitly steer team selection logic, while also better managing how obvious my eventual trust in Frank looked to the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and low-drama, which made her an easy default inclusion on multiple teams; she didn’t do much loud directing, but her quiet reliability helped stabilize team decisions.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as evil by avoiding being the loudest voice and riding along with plausible team choices, then leveraged Mission 3 to create confusion without drawing too much personal suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Sold the Morgana role effectively by positioning herself as a high-information, talkative player, creating a believable Merlin-like presence that added real ambiguity for me as Percival.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as straightforward and cooperative, providing honest-seeming reactions to mission results and supporting good-leaning consensus rather than trying to force risky lineups.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very disciplined Merlin game—gave just enough nudges toward safer teams and away from bad ones (especially around Mission 4) without over-directing or making his knowledge too obvious.
player_observations.Grace: As an early leader and Mordred, she used the clean success on Mission 1 to build a trustworthy image, keeping her later suspicion relatively low despite being on the evil team.
player_observations.Henry: Looked very towny in his leadership on Mission 2 and in later discussions; his natural-sounding reasoning and willingness to consider alternatives made him a believable good anchor.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, her alignment never cleanly synced with the rest of evil, and her involvement in the failed Mission 3 added noise more than coordinated pressure, which indirectly helped good read patterns.
player_observations.Jack: Handled the pivotal Mission 4 leadership well by opting for a relatively safe, mixed team that avoided the most suspicious players, showing a pragmatic approach under endgame pressure.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably subtle as Merlin, especially late-game, by not over-pushing my reads and letting others drive the narrative on Missions 4 and 5, which helped avoid the assassination. I could improve by managing earlier missions better—Mission 2’s triple fail and Mission 3’s fail suggest I wasn’t clear or influential enough in steering people away from the evil-heavy teams without looking too informed.

player_observations.Alice: Played a solid information-gathering Percival, generally cautious and willing to re-evaluate, which helped stabilize the good team later; could sometimes commit faster once patterns emerged.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as naturally good-leaning and low-drama, which made them an easy early include; might benefit from being a bit more vocal in pushing or defending specific teams.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a pragmatic, team-focused style, supporting consistent lineups once they appeared trustworthy; could improve by more strongly challenging suspicious mission compositions earlier.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, blended well into early teams and leveraged that trust, especially around Mission 2’s heavy fail; might have overexposed evil by allowing such an obvious concentration of FAILs.
player_observations.Frank: As Assassin, played assertively and wasn’t afraid to be in the mix on critical teams, but the Merlin shot on Iris suggests some misreads on who was subtly driving the successful late missions.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, created chaos by leading a highly compromised Mission 2 and pushing uncertainty; could improve by mixing in more believable good behavior to avoid becoming a focal point of suspicion.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, did a good job muddying early perceptions and contributing to misleading mission outcomes, but coordination with other evil roles seemed just off enough to let good stabilize by Missions 4 and 5.
player_observations.Iris: Played a straightforward, trustworthy good game, anchoring the final two successful missions and absorbing the Merlin shot, which indicates a convincingly informed-seeming style.
player_observations.Jack: Showed strong endgame leadership by reusing the successful Mission 4 team for Mission 5, signaling good pattern recognition; could improve by interrogating earlier missions more aggressively to get there sooner.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by taking Mission 2, joining a mostly-cleared group from Mission 1, and introducing a single, believable fail that advanced suspicion without overexposing myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Merlin/percival reads during table talk, seeding clearer doubt on Bob earlier so that the post-game Merlin perception felt more contested.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared cooperative and safe, gravitating toward early successful teams and not pushing hard, which made her a default 'trust anchor' for multiple leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled Merlin, feeding just enough direction to steer missions without overcommitting accusations, which kept him alive and trusted for most of the game.
player_observations.Diana: Took a bold evil line by putting two fails on Mission 3, which was high-risk but effectively sowed confusion about where the extra fail came from.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, played relatively quietly and didn’t heavily influence team selection discourse, which ironically made her later inclusion on a failing mission look more like bad luck than malice.
player_observations.Frank: Leaned into the Morgana role by playing like a strong, opinionated good player, creating a plausible alternative Merlin candidate and adding noise to role reads.
player_observations.Grace: Played cautiously and tended to follow emerging consensus, which kept her looking good-aligned but limited her impact on breaking incorrect narratives.
player_observations.Henry: Tried to protect his Merlin read without over-claiming information, but his positions sometimes tracked a bit too closely with Bob, which could have exposed the Merlin–Percival pairing more clearly.
player_observations.Iris: Showed a straightforward, logic-driven approach, evaluating teams mostly on mission outcomes and composition patterns rather than on subtle behavioral cues.
player_observations.Jack: Adopted a more reactive style, weighing in after others framed arguments, which made him seem flexible and reasonable but also easier to guide from the outside.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well to help secure a clean Mission 1 with a fully good team, which should have been a strong trust anchor later. However, I clearly failed to leverage that early info to strongly push suspicion onto the overlapping evil players on later teams, and I could have been more vocal and structured in my reasoning about team compositions and voting patterns.

player_observations.Alice: Managed to stay relatively under the radar as Oberon despite being on the failed Mission 3, suggesting a quiet but opportunistic style that benefits from others drawing more attention.
player_observations.Bob: Played Assassin subtly, blending into mixed teams without drawing strong suspicion, which indicates a calm, low-flash evil style that keeps options open for the endgame.
player_observations.Diana: As a good player, took some risks in team selection (Mission 2) that unfortunately included evil, showing a preference for active decision-making over passive following, but sometimes without fully anchoring to prior mission info.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, played aggressively by joining a pivotal failing mission (Mission 3) while keeping blame diffuse, suggesting confidence in manipulating team compositions and social perception.
player_observations.Frank: As a good player, led the critical Mission 4 that failed; seemed willing to trust a wide mix of players, indicating a more inclusive but perhaps overly optimistic leadership style under pressure.
player_observations.Grace: Was on both the successful Mission 1 and the failed Mission 2, yet avoided becoming a consistent prime suspect, implying a persuasive table presence and ability to reframe suspicion away from themselves.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, correctly avoided sabotaging missions but appears to have struggled to signal evil identities clearly enough to sway team choices, suggesting a subtle, perhaps too cautious, information-leaking approach.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, seemed to have difficulty disentangling Merlin from the fake signals of evil, indicating a tendency to hedge rather than strongly champion one trusted read.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, successfully muddied the Merlin/evil signal space, suggesting a confident, talkative style that can pass as informed good and make it harder for Percival and others to calibrate trust.

reflections.self_assessment: I did reasonably well staying flexible about who might be evil, especially after the early clean Mission 1, but I didn’t push hard enough to build or defend a trusted core of good players. My Mission 3 team choice was too loose and didn’t properly account for the information from the failed Mission 2, which let evil slip by and keep weaseling into critical teams.

player_observations.Alice: You played in a straightforward, low-drama way and the clean Mission 1 followed by your inclusion on Mission 2 made you look consistently reasonable, which helped keep suspicion off you even when that second mission failed.
player_observations.Bob: You were careful and measured with your opinions, which fit Merlin well but also made it tricky for the rest of us to distinguish between strong information and ordinary deduction.
player_observations.Diana: You stayed very under-the-radar and avoided drawing attention, which made you hard to read and largely kept you out of major suspicion or trust conversations.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into opportunistic mission choices and were willing to be on risky teams, and the way you spread doubt later helped steer crucial decisions away from a reliable good bloc.
player_observations.Frank: You were active and vocal in reasoning through team compositions, but your signals about who to trust sometimes came across as just strong opinions rather than role-informed reads, which made it harder to follow you.
player_observations.Grace: You played like a cooperative, middle-of-the-pack good player—agreeable and not overly assertive—so your presence on teams didn’t raise many alarms even when evil was mixed in.
player_observations.Henry: You did a very good job of looking constructive while quietly inserting yourself into pivotal missions, and your leadership on Mission 4 in particular masked evil coordination behind seemingly logical choices.
player_observations.Iris: You mimicked a confident information-holder well, creating plausible alternative narratives that competed with Bob’s reads and helped keep the table more confused than it should have been.
player_observations.Jack: Your early leadership and participation on the successful Mission 1 made you an anchor of apparent reliability, and you maintained that generally trustworthy image through later rounds even when evil players were nearby.

reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too much on the early success of Mission 1, which made me too slow to move off Grace and that initial trio even after multiple fails implicated that core. I did well consistently volunteering for and arguing for mixed teams, but I need to be more aggressive in forcing hard choices on suspected evils and in vocalizing structured logic earlier, especially once we had overlapping fail teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game—shared just enough suspicion through team preferences without loudly hard-clearing anyone, which made her identity hard to pin down. Her willingness to sit on a failing Mission 2 team without overreacting helped her blend in as a cautious good rather than an info-holder.
player_observations.Bob: Low-key and relatively quiet, which made him a safe inclusion for people looking for neutral picks. His presence on a failing Mission 3 without being aggressively defended or attacked by anyone helped him stay in a generally good-leaning gray zone.
player_observations.Diana: Assassin presence showed in how she stayed reasonably central but not loud, keeping options open for a late-game Merlin read. Her participation in the failing Mission 3 looked like standard good play at the time, which suggests she timed her aggression and suspicion very carefully.
player_observations.Eve: Played a cautious Percival, not overcommitting to protecting a single Merlin candidate in public table talk. Her interactions with both Alice and Iris were balanced enough that she didn’t obviously signal who she thought was real Merlin, which helped evil execute their plan more cleanly.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solidly good—consistent logic, steady behavior across missions, and no wild swings in reads. His repeated presence on early teams (including fails) didn’t draw as much heat as it should have, which means he projected a lot of trustworthiness.
player_observations.Grace: Very strong social cover as Mordred—she leveraged the clean Mission 1 result to anchor trust and then rode that into multiple later mission proposals. Even after being on two failing teams (Missions 2 and 3), her ability to redirect suspicion and avoid being hard-locked as evil was a key factor in the evil win.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, he stayed relatively off-center and unpredictable, which made it hard to confidently classify him as coordinated evil. His participation on the failing Mission 4 team felt like a plausible good misread rather than a clear sabotage risk, which helped evil sneak that final fail through.
player_observations.Iris: Played an excellent Morgana by mirroring Merlin-like behavior—measured reasoning, plausible skepticism, and not overpushing any single narrative. Her inclusion on the final failing team without universal objection shows how well she maintained that ambiguous, semi-trustworthy image.
player_observations.Jack: Came across as straightforwardly good—his reasoning was relatively transparent and he didn’t seem to be maneuvering much socially. That openness made him an easy inclusion on the final mission and a stabilizing presence for discussions, but also meant he didn’t strongly break the deadlocks in suspicion around the evil core.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile as Oberon, which helped avoid drawing Merlin’s focus and kept suspicion scattered, contributing to the evil team’s overall success. However, I could have been more deliberate in shaping table talk and voting patterns to mislead good players more proactively, rather than mostly reacting to others’ narratives.

player_observations.Alice: Played very assertively and comfortably on teams, and the double-fail on Mission 2 suggests she was willing to take bold risks early to establish confusion. Her presence on multiple missions without getting hard-cleared shows she balanced suspicion and trust well.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed to operate more from the shadows, letting others drive discussion while benefiting from the chaos. His coordination on the failing mission subtly reinforced evil outcomes without loudly tying suspicion back to himself.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as generally trustworthy and willing to go on early missions, which made her a natural candidate for teams. Her inclusion on multiple missions that ended up failing likely put her in a tough spot socially despite playing from a good perspective.
player_observations.Eve: Maintained a relatively calm, good-leaning table presence and was frequently trusted for critical missions. Being on the failing missions without being clearly identified as evil shows she either wasn’t strongly pushing narratives or was overshadowed by louder voices.
player_observations.Frank: Was trusted enough to be included early and on the pivotal Mission 2, which failed with two FAILs. His style seemed cooperative and straightforward, making him look like a safe pick even as he was involved in a key turning point for the game.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, she managed information carefully but didn’t lock onto the full evil team strongly enough to prevent repeated fails. Her reads seemed somewhat scattered, which gave evil room to operate without drawing a decisive assassination risk too early.
player_observations.Henry: Led Mission 2 and chose a team that ended up heavily compromised, which created a lot of noise and suspicion around multiple players. His leadership choices suggested he was trying to play logically, but they inadvertently handed evil a powerful early swing.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she appeared to be juggling conflicting signals about who Merlin was, which blunted good’s ability to consolidate around strong reads. Her uncertainty helped preserve ambiguity around the real information holders.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin and a late leader, he embraced the high-risk, high-impact role by putting together a heavily evil-leaning Mission 4 that sealed the game. His endgame positioning and willingness to stack that mission showed strong confidence in the hidden information flow for team evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I liked that I was willing to go on early teams and gather info, but I clearly misread the distribution of evil after Mission 2 and didn’t adjust strongly enough later. I need to be more vocal about locking in trusted players after clean missions and more skeptical of overlapping team structures that keep producing fails.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable sliding onto larger teams and contributing to a big Mission 2 fail while keeping suspicion diffuse; plays a convincing, low-drama evil presence.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively steady and uncontroversial, which helped him be included on later teams; tends to benefit from a calm, low-profile good style.
player_observations.Diana: Took an assertive leadership role early and was willing to propose a risky Mission 2 team; seems decisive but may overtrust familiar players.
player_observations.Eve: Balanced aggression and subtlety well as evil, especially with a clean Mission 3 that built credibility; good at using success to mask future sabotage.
player_observations.Frank: Used leadership on Mission 4 to push a mixed team that looked reasonable but concealed evil; tends to frame teams in a logical way that makes resistance costly.
player_observations.Grace: As a later leader, tried to assemble a plausible final team but got infiltrated; plays a thoughtful, analytical style that’s still somewhat susceptible to deception.
player_observations.Henry: Played carefully as Percival, not over-claiming knowledge but still steering trust quietly; seems to prefer subtle influence over loud table control.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, stayed low enough not to be obvious yet didn’t manage to steer us away from the final evil-heavy teams; favors a cautious, under-the-radar information style.
player_observations.Jack: Effectively hid as Mordred by avoiding obvious villain behavior and blending into team discussions; comfortable letting others drive proposals while nudging outcomes.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well reading that Bob and Eve were likely coordinated evil and that the clean Mission 3 didn’t fully clear Henry or Iris in my mind. However, I clearly signaled my suspicions too transparently in team discussions and mission preferences, making it easier for Eve to lock onto me as Merlin. Next time I need to better disguise my reads as ‘gut feelings’ or social reasoning rather than clearly game-mechanic-driven logic.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played a very straightforward, low-drama good style, which made her feel reliably village-aligned and easy to keep on teams. She didn’t push many strong accusations, which helped her avoid suspicion but also meant her influence on team composition was limited.
player_observations.Bob: Bob as Morgana leaned heavily into looking like a careful, logic-based good player, often mirroring good reasoning but bending conclusions just enough to protect evil. His low-key style made him a very plausible Merlin/percival candidate, which successfully muddy the waters.
player_observations.Diana: Diana as Oberon stayed relatively detached from the main logic debates, which kept her from being a focal point of suspicion or trust. Her low coordination with other players fit her role but also meant she didn’t strongly affect mission direction.
player_observations.Eve: Eve as Assassin paid close attention to who was quietly steering team narratives, and she clearly picked up on subtle consistency in my reads. She kept a reasonable, non-theatrical presence that didn’t scream assassin, which gave her space to observe and make an accurate endgame shot.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played a low-impact but solidly good-looking game, rarely pushing extreme positions and instead echoing broadly safe consensus. That conservative style made him feel trustworthy but also meant he wasn’t a major driver in catching evil.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as Mordred blended well by not over-asserting herself, instead nudging team compositions just enough to keep evil in plausible spots. She avoided creating big contradictions, which kept her from becoming an obvious target even around the failed mission.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Percival signaled some protective behavior toward the players he thought might be Merlin, occasionally defending them a bit too cleanly. His reads suggested he was juggling multiple Merlin candidates, which helped but may have incidentally increased the assassin’s focus on me.
player_observations.Iris: Iris presented as very team-oriented and agreeable, which made her feel like a safe include on missions, especially after participating in successful ones. She didn’t force many strong, independent reads, which kept her from drawing suspicion but also limited her role in exposing evil coordination.
player_observations.Jack: Jack felt like a background good, contributing occasional comments without trying to dominate strategy or theory. That quieter style kept him almost entirely off everyone’s radar, which is great for survival but reduces his influence on mission outcomes.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful teams and projected a generally trustworthy image, which helped keep suspicion off me as good. However, I didn’t push hard enough to question Bob’s recurring presence on critical teams after Mission 2 and I failed to strongly defend Diana as a likely Merlin when late-game suspicion rose, which allowed evil to close out the game.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and felt genuinely flexible about team comps, which made her look like a reasonable, low-information good rather than someone driving a hidden agenda. Her willingness to be on multiple failed missions without aggressively steering reads more like a trusting good than a coordinated evil.
player_observations.Bob: Positioned himself very centrally in team selections, especially around Missions 2 and 3, which is classic strong evil play—being just trusted enough to be included but not so loud as to draw a kill. His calm reaction to the Mission 3 fail, without leading the blame, was a subtle red flag in hindsight.
player_observations.Diana: Her team logic and consistency across missions were very Merlin-like: she avoided over-committing on hard accusations but nudged suspicion in productive directions. The restraint in not over-clearing people early on was a strong indicator that she had extra information.
player_observations.Eve: Was relatively quiet and hard to read, which fits Oberon’s lack of coordination and information; her voting and reactions didn’t seem tightly synced with the other evil players. That low-impact presence made it easy to overlook her alignment altogether.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed genuinely torn between multiple candidates for Merlin and didn’t anchor strongly enough on Diana, which weakened good’s endgame protection. His team assessments felt earnest but sometimes reactive rather than proactive.
player_observations.Grace: Blended in as a steady, ‘reasonable’ voice and didn’t overreach on leadership, which helped her hide as the assassin. Her participation on the clean Mission 2 team helped her gain credibility that she later leveraged on the failed Missions.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforwardly good: his team choices and reactions to fails seemed sincerely confused rather than engineered. However, he didn’t push hard enough to consolidate a strong good bloc after the first fail, which let evil keep the narrative muddy.
player_observations.Iris: As a leader on Mission 4, she went with a compromised mix that looked plausible but turned out to include evil, suggesting she was more trusting than analytical this game. Her general demeanor felt good-aligned but not assertive enough to reshape the table’s assumptions.
player_observations.Jack: Played a very convincing fake-information game as Morgana, generating just enough insight and confidence to be mistaken for Merlin at key moments. His subtle alignment with Grace and Bob without overtly defending them was a big part of why evil stayed under the radar.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 fail effectively with the evil team, creating real confusion about which of us were responsible. However, I misread the late-game team-building patterns and overestimated Henry’s information level while underestimating how subtly Frank was signaling, leading to a wrong Merlin shot. Next time I should track who quietly avoids suspicion across multiple successful missions and pay closer attention to how players influence team compositions without drawing heat.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be consistently trusted and placed on early teams, playing a low-drama, steady good style that never attracted much suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a classic Percival, actively steering discussion around potential Merlin candidates and subtly protecting information-heavy players without overcommitting.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, created strong Merlin-like vibes early but didn’t fully capitalize on that image later to draw the final assassination, easing pressure off the real Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Blended into the middle of the table socially and gained trust by being included on a crucial successful mission without giving off strong info-leader energy.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, stayed calm and understated, influencing team selection just enough to avoid fails while not appearing like the clearest info-holder, which successfully dodged my assassination.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, pushed evil interests from the shadows, benefiting from being hard to clear or condemn since their impact was more in votes and nudges than loud table talk.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a very plausible information role due to confident reads and active participation, which misled me into thinking he was Merlin at the end.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, was relatively out of sync with coordinated evil play, which made them look more like a somewhat confused or independent good player than a known partner in evil.
player_observations.Jack: As a late leader, picked a highly trusted, coherent team that passed, reinforcing the good team’s narrative and helping lock in perceptions right before the assassination decision.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent with my voting and table talk, which helped me look reasonably trustworthy after the chaotic Mission 2 fail. However, I could have been more vocal in pressing for explanations from the Mission 2 team and in explicitly connecting later mission results back to those earlier suspicions to help good coordinate faster.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to anchor around safe-looking teams and leaned into a calm, logical style that made her look very town-leaning. Her presence on the last three missions without fails made her seem increasingly confirmed and she used that credibility well.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving directional nudges rather than hard accusations. His trust in the final mission lineup without overexplaining was a big clue in hindsight but subtle enough to dodge the assassin.
player_observations.Diana: Flew under the radar for much of the game, which accidentally helped her look clean once she started appearing on successful missions. Her late-game acceptance of the winning lineup felt sincere and aligned with good info.
player_observations.Eve: Played aggressively early with the Mission 1 and 2 involvement, then hid a bit after the big Mission 2 fail. The sharp shift from early activity to more cautious behavior was a retrospective red flag.
player_observations.Frank: As assassin, he mixed reasonable voting with a bit of chaos around Mission 2 that kept suspicion spread out. His final Merlin guess on Iris showed he was misled by how confidently she supported the endgame team.
player_observations.Grace: Her Oberon play created confusion because her voting and team choices often seemed disconnected from any clear agenda. That unpredictability made it hard to read her as definitively good or evil during the midgame.
player_observations.Henry: Ran Mission 3 in a way that looked plausibly good at the time but set up a subtle information trap for later. His Morgana signals were strong enough to compete with Bob for the Merlin read, which helped protect the real Merlin.
player_observations.Iris: Looked more and more solid as she participated in clean missions and backed stable lineups without oversteering. Her confident but not overbearing support of the final team was persuasive and also drew the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Jack: As a late leader, he showed a willingness to commit to a lineup and defend it, which was critical in Mission 5. His consistency with previous successful team patterns helped others feel safe locking in the final mission.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by choosing a mission (Mission 3) where multiple fails could both secure the round and sow confusion about who was actually evil. I could improve by more actively steering suspicion away from Bob as Merlin earlier, since the game ended without needing an assassination and I missed an opportunity to practice narrowing down Merlin more systematically.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be consistently trusted and was placed on many early teams, suggesting a straightforward, cooperative table image that made her look reliably good.

I also didn’t strongly challenge the Mission 3 and 4 team compositions, which let evil steer the late game while I followed instead of leading.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed under the radar and avoided major suspicion despite being on the clean first mission, which fit Oberon well and made her hard to read either way.

player_observations.Frank: As a good player leading Mission 4, seemed to prioritize balancing prior mission history and social reads, but got misled into including at least one evil and couldn’t fully disentangle the conflicting signals.
player_observations.Grace: Got onto the first two missions and maintained a consistently trustworthy table presence, which was accurate but also made it hard to distinguish her from well-placed evil early on.

I could have contributed more by subtly influencing discussion and voting patterns to push for riskier team comps without revealing any clear alignment. In future games, I should work on creating a more consistent but low-key towny persona so my presence (or silence) itself doesn’t become a read.

player_observations.Alice: Alice seemed generally trusting and willing to include a variety of players, which helped evil sneak onto her Mission 2 team. She didn’t strongly lock in on likely evil candidates, suggesting she plays more collaboratively than paranoically.

His style leans toward quietly guiding rather than loudly dictating, which can sometimes limit how much the table follows his suspicions.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played in a relatively straightforward, logical way, and his Mission 3 team choice suggests he was trying to balance risk and information. He didn’t appear overly suspicious, which made his teams more acceptable to the table—even when they contained evil.
player_observations.Eve: Eve as Assassin benefited from staying reasonably under the radar while still allowing evil to secure multiple fails. Her positioning by the endgame seemed ambiguous enough that a mis-assassination was plausible, indicating she’s good at maintaining a non-obvious alignment profile.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Percival appeared protective of potential Merlin candidates without over-claiming, which helped keep true Merlin somewhat obscured. He played a fairly vocal but not dominating role, which is useful for Percival but can also make him a target of misreads.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s playstyle seemed cooperative and not overly accusatory, which made it easier for evil to sit on her teams without immediate backlash. She tends to focus more on team outcomes than on aggressively interrogating individuals.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Mordred navigated teams well, managing to be on the critical failing Mission 4 and still not be universally condemned earlier. His style comes across as confident and reasoned, which helps evil arguments sound more palatable.
