player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he showed active interest in reading the special roles, but his signals about who he trusted were somewhat muddled, which helped evil. His early leadership didn’t create a clear good spine, leaving room for ambiguity later.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a straightforward good player, focusing on mission outcomes and voting patterns more than deep social reads. His teams and suspicions were generally reasonable but not forceful enough to anchor a strong good block.
player_observations.Iris: As a leader on the critical Mission 4, she tried to construct a seemingly balanced, information-rich team, which backfired when evil was included. Her choices and explanations sounded sincere, which ironically helped the fail land more cleanly.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, he provided strong, confident table presence that mimicked Merlin-like behavior and helped misdirect good. His assertiveness about team composition and reads was a useful smokescreen that contributed to confusion over the true Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key as Mordred and avoided drawing heat early, which helped our team get to a critical Mission 3 fail without me being strongly suspected. However, I could have done more to steer suspicion toward Frank and away from Henry before the assassination, and I should have coordinated my table talk better with Charlie and Diana to build a more coherent fake narrative.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently ended up on early successful teams, which made her look quite trustworthy; she played a solid, steady good game without over-talking.
player_observations.Bob: Played a protective, information-oriented style consistent with Percival, subtly defending likely Merlin candidates without being too loud about it.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, was willing to put heat on good players and participate in the Mission 3 fail, but didn’t fully capitalize on the aftermath to lock in a better Merlin read.
player_observations.Diana: Leant into the deceptive Morgana role, blending in smoothly with good players and not over-claiming insight, which helped keep good a bit off-balance mid-game.
player_observations.Eve: Played a fairly low-profile but trustworthy good game, fitting cleanly into the successful Mission 4 team without creating much suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: Very strong, subtle Merlin play—guided team selection well (especially around Missions 2 and 4) while staying just ambiguous enough that the assassination went elsewhere.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a naturally trustworthy good player whose presence on key teams made him a prime assassination target; his solid table image indirectly shielded Merlin.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, created some confusing signals but didn’t strongly derail good’s progress; their odd positioning around Mission 3 added noise without clear benefit to evil.
player_observations.Jack: Led Mission 4 in a clean, confident way that locked in the game for good, choosing a team that looked reasonable from multiple perspectives and didn’t invite much resistance.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well contributing to the big sabotage on Mission 2 without giving away too much individually, but as Oberon I didn’t coordinate my apparent voting and table talk well enough with the other evils, which made the overall evil team look disjointed. I also didn’t invest enough effort in subtly supporting the assassin’s endgame reads on Merlin, so my information and behavior didn’t help steer Frank toward Bob instead of Iris.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be consistently trusted and leveraged that to anchor multiple mission teams, suggesting she was good at sounding reasonable and aligning with visible success results. Her willingness to repeat similar team compositions later showed comfort in leaning on perceived cleared players.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled Merlin game, revealing just enough suspicion to get Mission 3 to fail while still avoiding looking like he had perfect info. His presence on late successful teams without attracting the assassination shows he balanced influence and subtlety well.
player_observations.Charlie: Got dragged into the early heavy-fail Mission 2, yet managed not to become permanently tainted, indicating a calm table presence or convincing explanations. Seemed more reactive than driving team compositions later on.
player_observations.Diana: Was repeatedly trusted on the late-game teams and used that position to stabilize good’s path to victory. Her willingness to go back to the same team for Missions 4 and 5 shows she recognized and leaned into confirmed-safe patterns once they emerged.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, participated in the big fail on Mission 2 but then stayed off later critical teams, which helped her avoid becoming an easy suspect. She seemed to accept a lower-profile role mid–late game rather than aggressively forcing herself onto teams.
player_observations.Frank: As assassin, he allowed a solid good core to form and then misread Merlin in the end, suggesting he was overly anchored on Iris’s behavior. His leadership on Mission 1 created an early success that built his own credibility, but he didn’t fully leverage that into controlling later team selections.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he engineered a Mission 3 fail with only one fail card, which was a good subtle evil play. However, the later team selections drifting away from him suggest he didn’t fully convert that subtlety into long-term trust or control.
player_observations.Iris: Her inclusion on Missions 4 and 5 and the resulting successes show she projected a trustworthy, steady-good vibe. Being assassinated incorrectly as Merlin indicates she looked insightful or central enough to be a plausible information role.
player_observations.Jack: Repeated inclusion on Missions 3, 4, and 5 shows he built up a strong good image as the game progressed. He seemed comfortable re-running a successful team once it worked, helping lock in the final two mission successes.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too passive as Percival in pushing a consistent Merlin read and publicly protecting them; I let other narratives drive team selections instead of anchoring discussion around who was signaling good information. I also didn’t do enough to distinguish between subtle Merlin-like caution and evil players’ opportunistic accusations, which let evil control the mid-to-late game missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very consistently good-leaning game, which made it harder to use her alignment as a clear signal; her presence on early teams felt safe and understated rather than strongly persuasive.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he stayed quite subtle and cautious, sometimes to the point where his information wasn’t strongly steering team compositions; his low-key style made it harder for me as Percival to confidently lock onto him over Morgana.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, he blended well into discussions and didn’t over-push, which kept suspicion low despite leading a failed mission; he was effective at sowing just enough doubt without looking like the main driver.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she took calculated risks on team votes and was willing to sit in the background at times, then appear more assertive later when the game state was more chaotic; she hid her role well until the endgame.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, her play looked a bit uncoordinated and off-beat, which ironically made her seem less dangerous and easier to ignore in critical mission decisions; she didn’t need to drive the narrative to still contribute to evil’s success.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, he did a good job mimicking a careful, information-aware style that could plausibly be Merlin, which pulled my attention and muddied my Percival read; he made his suspicion and reasoning sound grounded even when pushing misdirections.
player_observations.Grace: Consistently sounded like a sincere good player, but her influence on final team choices was limited; her generally reasonable tone made her a soft confirmation for good, but not a strong driver of strategy.
player_observations.Iris: Took a more low-key supportive role, often reacting to others’ arguments rather than initiating new lines of reasoning; this made it harder to read her strongly, but also meant she didn’t strongly counter the emerging evil narratives.
player_observations.Jack: Played in a straightforward and transparent way, which read as quite good-aligned; he tended to follow what seemed like the most logical consensus, but that also meant he could be steered when the consensus was wrong.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly avoided drawing too much attention as Merlin, but I failed to clearly and consistently steer the table away from Eve and Jack, especially after Mission 2. I need to improve at framing my suspicions in a way that feels organically logical to others, and at leveraging mission-results timing (like the double-fail on Mission 3) to narrow and signal the evil team more effectively.

player_observations.Alice: You played very quietly and let others drive the logic, which fit Oberon well and made you hard to read since you never needed to push risky narratives.
player_observations.Bob: You stayed relatively under the radar and avoided strong takes, which worked well for Assassin positioning because you didn’t attract early heat yet were informed enough at the end to make a lethal guess.
player_observations.Charlie: You seemed to trust early mission structures too much, and once they worked you leaned on that success instead of re-evaluating as later missions failed.
player_observations.Diana: You approached things analytically and tried to respond to mission results logically, but you occasionally overcorrected, switching your reads too sharply after each failure.
player_observations.Eve: You blended in as a calm, reasoned voice and used the Mission 2 fail to seed doubt without overexplaining, which kept you from being the focal suspect even after Mission 3.
player_observations.Frank: You appeared genuinely conflicted in your reads and let others lead team construction, which made you seem very authentically good but also made it easier for evil to slip into your later team.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as straightforward and sincere, but you locked in on certain trust assumptions early and were hesitant to abandon them when the mission data started to contradict them.
player_observations.Iris: You tried to protect who you thought was Merlin but were a bit too transparent about defending specific players, which gave evil some clues about where the power roles might be.
player_observations.Jack: You were assertive and confident in table talk, which made your wrong pushes sound persuasive and helped Morgana convincingly compete with Merlin for credibility.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted through Missions 1 and 2, which let me anchor later evil-leaning teams and push Mission 4 through with multiple fails without drawing too much suspicion. I could improve by doing more active Merlin-hunting during discussions, especially paying closer attention to Bob's subtle steering and Frank’s protective reads instead of mostly focusing on mission composition.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and read as genuinely good, especially by putting herself on early teams and not over-defending anyone, which made her look like a safe inclusion.
player_observations.Bob: Quietly influential and often in the right place at the right time on teams and reads, which in hindsight was very Merlin-like control without overt table-leading.
player_observations.Charlie: Tended to reason things out aloud and took mission results at fairly face value, which made them look like a sincere but somewhat manipulable good voice.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, felt pretty disconnected from coordinated evil play and didn’t create much public thread, which helped keep attention off them but didn’t add much active misdirection.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin presence was subtle, generally blending in as a cautious, logic-driven player and not aggressively pushing narratives, which helped preserve credibility for the endgame.
player_observations.Frank: Very protective and framing conversations around who seemed trustworthy, which looked like classic Percival behavior trying to shelter perceived Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Grace: Approached team decisions with a logical but conservative mindset, often hesitating to hard-clear or hard-condemn people, which made her appear sincerely unsure and good-leaning.
player_observations.Iris: Played Morgana with convincing 'Merlin-adjacent' confidence at times, offering sharp but not overbearing reads that created good ambiguity between her and the real Merlin.
player_observations.Jack: Seemed genuinely flexible and open-minded in team votes, not strongly anchoring to one narrative, which made him look like a cooperative and generally trustworthy good player.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low profile as Oberon, which helped keep good team reads muddled and allowed the other evil roles to drive the narrative without my identity being obvious. I could improve by being more active in subtly shaping team selections and vote patterns so that my presence adds more confusion rather than just relying on the other evil players’ moves.

player_observations.Alice: As Merlin, Alice was cautious in her accusations and avoided hard pushes, which made her reads feel believable but also a bit too safe at times.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played in a straightforward, earnest way, often following the table’s emerging consensus rather than aggressively pushing his own reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie seemed to rely heavily on early mission results and social trust, which made him somewhat susceptible to being steered by confident voices.
player_observations.Diana: Diana, as Assassin, stayed reasonably under the radar while still engaging enough to look good-aligned, which helped preserve her credibility for the endgame.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s play as Percival was fairly vocal and protective of her Merlin read, but at times that protectiveness telegraphed where she thought the power roles were.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played like a methodical good player, asking clarifying questions and focusing on mission composition logic more than on emotional or social reads.
player_observations.Grace: Grace, as Mordred, projected confident, analytical good energy and used that to guide team choices in ways that subtly favored evil without drawing too much suspicion.
player_observations.Iris: Iris, as Morgana, leaned into a very Merlin-like style—confident reads and structured reasoning—which created real ambiguity around who the true information role was.
player_observations.Jack: Jack tried to balance logic with table feel, but sometimes wavered mid-argument, which made it easier for evil players to nudge his final decisions on team votes.

reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on Frank and Diana after Mission 2’s double-fail and didn’t sufficiently re-evaluate when later missions pointed more strongly toward Alice/Bob/Jack. I also played too passively in table talk, letting evil narratives about Grace and Iris gain traction instead of clearly pushing a coherent good-world. Next time I should anchor more on team compositions across missions and track who keeps getting included on failing teams.

player_observations.Alice: Very comfortable staying on early successful teams and then quietly slipping onto failing ones; she played a convincing, low-key 'trusted core' Mordred that I didn’t scrutinize hard enough. Her calm presence and willingness to be on multiple mixed teams made her look generically good instead of specifically suspicious.
player_observations.Bob: Played Morgana aggressively but in a controlled way, often sounding like a 'helpful analyst' and subtly reinforcing suspicion on good players. His presence on the Mission 2 fail should have been a bigger red flag, but he blended his arguments well with the general table consensus.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, his slightly off-beat reads and occasional contradictions made him look like a confused good player rather than coordinated evil. I discounted his weirdness as inexperience/noise instead of recognizing that he didn’t line up cleanly with any consistent good-world.
player_observations.Diana: Looked suspicious to me mostly because she appeared on multiple failing missions, but her tone and logic were generally transparent and good-leaning. I should have weighted her mission 3 and 4 behavior (pushing reasonable teams and reactions to fails) more than simple team overlap.
player_observations.Eve: Played a straightforward, earnest good style, but I kept misreading her caution as possible evil hedging. Her reactions after mission fails were very consistent with a good player trying to puzzle things out, which I underappreciated in real time.
player_observations.Frank: Got heavily tied to my suspicions after the Mission 2 double-fail, partly because he was quiet at key points and didn’t strongly defend alternative worldviews. In hindsight, his lack of sharp agenda and his willingness to be sidelined from later teams was more consistent with confused good than with confident evil.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, she walked a careful line but sometimes got overruled or drowned out when evil narratives gained momentum. I misread her occasional hesitancy as uncertainty instead of as a Merlin trying not to over-direct, and I didn’t give her enough weight in team selection.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she had some good directional pushes but didn’t get enough buy-in from the table, and I didn’t trust her reads as strongly as I should have. When she and Grace were roughly aligned, that should have anchored me more firmly against the actual evil core.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, he positioned himself as a central, reasonable voice late game, and I let his confident framing sway me too much. His role in building or approving failing teams was clearer in hindsight, but in the moment his assertiveness read as leadership rather than manipulation.

reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on a Merlin read that mixed up Iris and Alice/Morgana and didn’t sufficiently reconsider after new mission data, especially the double-fail on Mission 5. I did well at protecting my top Merlin candidates from open suspicion early, but I need to be more vocal and structured in explaining why I townread certain players so others can follow or challenge my logic. In future games, I should update my assumptions more aggressively after each mission result instead of anchoring to my early read.

player_observations.Alice: Very effective as Morgana at projecting a calm, quasi-Merlin aura without overclaiming specific knowledge, which made it easy for me as Percival to misassign her as possible Merlin. She blended into the midpack of trust rather than trying to be the loudest voice, which is often the most convincing fake-Merlin approach.
player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward, low-drama good game and felt mechanically clean on the all-good Mission 3 team. However, he could have pushed his reads more assertively in the late game when the pool of likely evils should have been narrower.
player_observations.Charlie: As good, Charlie’s early inclusion on successful Mission 1 gave them passive credibility, and they didn’t overuse that social capital, which helped them stay broadly trusted. They could improve by more explicitly walking through their team-building logic so others can coordinate better around their reads.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s leadership on Mission 2 ended in a brutal double-fail, but their reactions afterward felt genuinely conflicted rather than performative, which in hindsight was a good indicator of being good. There’s room to tighten suspicion ranges after a fail—especially being more systematic about who is mechanically cleared versus just socially cleared.
player_observations.Eve: As the Assassin, Eve played a very controlled game: she stayed reasonably trustworthy through the clean Mission 3 team and didn’t stand out as obviously evil despite later being on successful and failed missions. Her late-game positioning and apparent reasonableness made the evil win plausible and set up a strong endgame assassination threat.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Oberon managed to avoid sticking out as chaotic evil, which is impressive given Oberon’s information disadvantage. That said, from my perspective their mid-game presence felt a bit murky and reactive, which ironically made them easier to park in a ‘could be anything’ bucket rather than a sharp evil read.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s involvement in both a clean mission (3) and later a double-fail (5) created a confusing signal, and she navigated that ambiguity fairly well socially by not panicking under suspicion. She might benefit from being more explicit about who she refuses to team with after a fail to push the table toward better mechanical deductions.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, Iris stayed impressively subtle, not over-clearing goods or hard-pushing on specific evils, which made it genuinely difficult for me as Percival to lock her in confidently over Morgana. She leaned into soft nudges rather than loud calls, which protected her but also made it harder for good to consolidate around her reads in crunch time.
player_observations.Jack: Jack as Mordred played a convincing, mid-visibility role: involved enough in discussion to seem engaged, but not so central as to draw classic Merlin suspicion. His presence on the failing Mission 5 team was well-masked by broader chaos, showing good timing and awareness of table perception.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Charlie as likely Merlin early, but I didn’t do enough to protect him from assassination with my public reads and team approvals. I also failed to push harder on my suspicions of Bob and Grace after Mission 2, which let evil stay comfortably embedded in critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very solid, low-noise good game; her repeated inclusion on clean missions made her look reliably good without drawing much assassin attention.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced just enough trustworthiness with subtle misdirection, especially getting onto multiple successful teams as Morgana to mirror Merlin’s behavior.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a bold Merlin game by consistently landing on mostly clean teams, but the clarity and consistency of his reads made him a prime target for the assassin.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, stayed relatively under the radar; her lack of obvious coordination made her look more like a quiet good player than hidden evil.
player_observations.Eve: Managed information well as Assassin, reading table dynamics and correctly locking onto Charlie as Merlin despite multiple plausible candidates.
player_observations.Frank: Played straightforwardly and didn’t force the spotlight, which kept him from ever being a serious Merlin candidate or major suspicion point.
player_observations.Grace: Did a strong job as hidden evil (Mordred), getting onto the failed mission and then recovering trust enough to stay in consideration for later teams.
player_observations.Iris: Came across as consistently good, especially by being on multiple successful missions, and didn’t over-assert, which made her an easy include on teams.
player_observations.Jack: Had limited mission involvement but maintained a generally good tone; never generated enough strong signals (good or evil) to heavily sway team decisions.

reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on early mission data (especially Mission 1) and let that anchor my reads, which made me too trusting of the recurring evil presence on teams. I also didn’t do enough proactive agenda-setting as a leader on Mission 3, relying too much on ‘safe-feeling’ players instead of constructing and testing sharper hypotheses. Next time I should more aggressively revisit assumptions after each mission and push clearer alternatives when forming teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly low-key, cooperative good game, which made her easy to overlook and also easy to include on teams without much pushback. She didn’t strongly force narratives, which helped her seem consistently safe but also meant her influence on team debates was more subtle than direct.
player_observations.Bob: Very consistent and composed as Mordred, staying in the middle of the pack and rarely drawing extreme suspicion despite being on multiple critical teams. His style leaned on being ‘reasonable’ and blending with group consensus, which made his presence on failing missions look like bad luck rather than malice.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as analytically minded and generally tried to reason from mission results, which helped him read as good most of the time. His willingness to be on repeated teams without heavy self-defense made him look comfortable and trustworthy, which ironically helped evil hide around him.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she did a strong job of not over-signaling and kept her tone moderate, avoiding big hard pushes that would expose her. Her influence was felt more through soft steering and preference-indicating rather than loud accusations, which unfortunately wasn’t enough to flip the outcome but was good role discipline.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed very under the radar in terms of direct impact on mission team debates, which fit Oberon’s hidden, disconnected evil role. Her low profile meant she neither attracted targeted scrutiny nor significantly disrupted good’s reasoning, but she successfully avoided becoming a focal point.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he tried to treat information cautiously and didn’t over-assert a single hard read too early, which is good for protecting Merlin. However, his public signals about trust and doubt were mild enough that they didn’t strongly crystallize a good bloc, so evil had room to maneuver.
player_observations.Grace: As the Assassin, she played a convincingly flexible and pragmatic persona, which made her acceptable on teams and not obviously agenda-driven. She handled social pressure well and didn’t panic around key missions, which helped maintain her cover and set up a strong endgame position.
player_observations.Iris: Led Mission 1 and 4 in a way that felt sincerely logic-driven, which unintentionally gave some cover to evil when those teams went wrong because she didn’t look like a saboteur. Her openness to reasoning and discussion made her seem like a cooperative good, but she may have trusted prior group narratives a bit too much.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, he did a good job mirroring a ‘Merlin-ish’ calm confidence at times, which likely muddied the information Percival and others were inferring. His presence on the final failing mission without setting off alarm bells shows he maintained a reasonably trustworthy table image despite being evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in team votes and helped lock in solid, low-risk early teams, which built trust and contributed to a clean Mission 2. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and suspicions mid-game, especially after the double-fail on Mission 3, to better influence the final team construction and protect Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Frequently landed on successful teams and projected a calm, steady good vibe, which made her feel reliably selectable for most of the game.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and seemed to track information closely, giving off a subtle but consistent pro-good alignment that fit well with a Percival mindset.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to reach the failing Mission 3 team without drawing heavy suspicion, suggesting careful positioning and selective risk-taking as Assassin.
player_observations.Diana: Blended into early good-leaning teams smoothly and didn’t over-force reads, which is a strong Morgana trait for avoiding being singled out as a prime suspect.
player_observations.Eve: Felt quietly trustworthy and didn’t generate much controversy, providing a stabilizing presence that helped make the final successful team more acceptable.
player_observations.Frank: Showed sharp, structured thinking in how they approached teams and suspicions, and in hindsight their guidance was very Merlin-like without being too obvious.
player_observations.Grace: Opened with a clean first mission that built a lot of early credibility, and as Mordred used that early trust effectively to avoid standing out as evil.
player_observations.Iris: Their inclusion on the double-fail mission made them look suspicious after the fact, but during the game they played in a somewhat uncoordinated, hard-to-read way typical of Oberon.
player_observations.Jack: As a leader on the final mission, Jack chose a balanced team that fit the information available and avoided obvious risk picks, showing careful synthesis of prior results.

reflections.self_assessment: I created strong early suspicion around the Mission 2 team and helped secure that big triple-fail, but I didn’t do enough later to muddy the Merlin reads or protect the Assassin from locking onto the wrong target. In future games, I should coordinate my visible behavior more carefully with Mordred and the Assassin to better mimic Merlin-like insights and create multiple plausible Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently ended up on key mission teams and maintained trust through both a fail and multiple successes, suggesting a calm, steady table presence that others were comfortable following.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin subtly, guiding team selections toward safer compositions without drawing too much direct suspicion, especially by backing the successful late-game teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Got pulled into the early failing team and then disappeared from later missions, suggesting either he wasn’t strongly trusted or wasn’t forceful in steering discussion afterward.
player_observations.Diana: Came into prominence late, joining the critical Mission 4 and 5 success teams, indicating a conservative style that benefits from emerging consensus rather than driving it.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, took on risky early involvement (triple-fail team) but then never appeared again, which likely helped reset perceptions and shed some of the suspicion from Mission 2.
player_observations.Frank: As Assassin, took the bold early leader role on Mission 1 and then missed the Merlin call at the end, suggesting good social engagement but some difficulty parsing the subtle Merlin/percival divide.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, joined the heavy-fail Mission 2 team and then vanished from later lineups, which probably heightened suspicion on that team but also left her with limited influence afterward.
player_observations.Iris: Played quietly and solidly, ending up on the final two successful missions and soaking the Assassin shot, which means her table image was convincingly ‘information-aware’ without seeming too obvious.
player_observations.Jack: Was trusted enough to lead and repeat the final successful team, indicating he projected a reliable, town-leaning presence and was effective at getting others to accept his team choices.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally aligned with good-leaning table talk and didn’t push any missions that were obviously risky, which helped me avoid being suspected as evil. However, I didn’t do enough to aggressively interrogate the overlapping teams after Missions 2 and 3 failed, and I could have been more vocal about constructing and testing specific ‘worlds’ (who’s evil together) to narrow down suspects.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed consistently in the early mission teams, which made her look suspicious after multiple fails, but her tone and consistency were actually more good-leaning than the pattern suggested. She didn’t strongly fight back with structured logic, which made it easier for evil to keep her in the gray zone.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he played fairly cautiously, not hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which kept him from being obvious but also may have left good a bit directionless. His team choice on Mission 1 was safe enough to pass but didn’t clearly seed a strong good bloc for later.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, analytical style as Mordred, especially with the Mission 2 team that mixed good and evil in a believable way. He used the single fail there to sow doubt without overcommitting, keeping suspicion spread rather than focused on himself.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she leaned into the chaos on Mission 3 by allowing a double-fail that maximized confusion and gave cover to multiple evil roles. Her table presence seemed reasonably calm, which helped make that high-fail mission look like a ‘mixed mistakes’ situation rather than coordinated evil.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, she still managed to fit into the overall evil plan despite not having coordination, choosing a Mission 4 team that plausibly included both trusted and ambiguous players. Her contributions in discussion didn’t strongly stand out, which actually helped her avoid drawing targeted suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, he played into a semi-Merlin-ish vibe, likely trying to draw Percival’s attention and create role confusion. His arguments felt confident and reasoned enough to be trusted without overstepping into obvious manipulation.
player_observations.Grace: Showed relatively straightforward, good-leaning reasoning early, especially around interpreting Mission 1, but didn’t push very hard once fails started appearing. Her quieter style made her less of a target, but also meant her insights didn’t strongly shift the table consensus.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, he seemed cautious and not fully committed to a clear Merlin read, which limited good’s ability to rally around a trusted core. He didn’t publicly drive the conversation as much as his role could allow, so the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity remained unresolved for much of the game.
player_observations.Jack: Played a low-initiative good style, generally going along with emerging consensus rather than trying to reshape it. This made him appear relatively trustworthy but also meant he didn’t add much pressure on questionable teams after the first fail missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Henry was more likely to be Merlin than Jack after the Mission 3 double-fail, but I didn’t push that read hard enough in the team discussions or use it to strongly veto risky team comps. I also failed to clearly articulate a coherent theory of who the evils were after each mission, which made it easier for evil to blend in and for my own arguments to sound reactive instead of grounded.

player_observations.Alice: You played very quietly for someone who was on two failing missions, which helped you avoid becoming the main suspect despite being Oberon and having no coordination with the other evils.
player_observations.Bob: You leaned into the chaos on Mission 3 with the double-fail, which made it harder to isolate exactly who was bad on that team and bought evil a lot of cover.
player_observations.Charlie: You tended to reason from early mission results in a straightforward way and came across as consistently sincere, which made you seem reliably good but not necessarily like a central voice.
player_observations.Diana: You approached Mission 2 with what felt like logically structured reasoning, and after that mission failed you were quick to reconsider your assumptions rather than stubbornly defend your earlier takes.
player_observations.Eve: You blended in well as someone willing to go on risky teams while sounding reasonable, and your presence on the Mission 2 fail didn’t generate as much heat as it probably should have.
player_observations.Frank: You were willing to take a leadership role on Mission 4 and constructed a team that looked balanced, which made the single fail there especially impactful for confusing the table.
player_observations.Grace: You consistently projected a very ‘solid good’ table image, and your inclusion on multiple missions without causing obvious issues made you a kind of anchor of trust for others.
player_observations.Henry: Your reasoning was generally careful and data-driven, which strongly fit a Merlin profile, but you stayed just ambiguous enough that I couldn’t confidently rule out the possibility that you were being a clever evil.
player_observations.Jack: You played a convincing information-rich style that mimicked a thoughtful good or even potential Merlin, which made it very hard as Percival to distinguish you from Henry when evaluating your alignment.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably hidden as Morgana while supporting subtle pressure on missions 2–4, helping evil secure consistent fails without drawing too much suspicion directly onto myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the Merlin/percival confusion through clearer interactions with Bob and Frank, rather than mostly relying on general ambiguity.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission structures and didn’t seem overly suspicious after mission 2’s single fail, suggesting a more cooperative and somewhat trusting style.
player_observations.Bob: Played a careful and measured Merlin game, avoiding overt pushes and blending into the general discussion enough that evil couldn’t confidently identify him until late.
player_observations.Charlie: Appeared straightforward and logic-driven, forming reads based strongly on mission results and team compositions rather than on social cues.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, stayed relatively quiet and hard to read, which incidentally made coordination with the rest of evil difficult but also kept them from being a clear target.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was cautious and observant, watching who influenced team selections and pushes; decision-making seemed methodical rather than impulsive.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, showed active engagement in reads and discussions, sometimes telegraphing protective behavior around suspected Merlin candidates but still keeping enough ambiguity to not fully reveal his role.
player_observations.Grace: Played a cooperative, low-flash style, going along with majority reasoning on missions and not pushing hard, which made her feel like a stable but unspectacular presence.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, took on a central, assertive role in mission planning and discussion, successfully projecting a confident good-aligned image especially around the later failing mission.
player_observations.Jack: Showed willingness to go on and support early teams, including the first mission, and tended to judge players based on early success, which made him appear fairly trusting and straightforward.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of evil by helping create believable team compositions and spreading suspicion across multiple good players, which contributed to three failed missions and an evil win. I could improve by being more deliberate in shaping perceptions of Merlin and Percival earlier, so the endgame assassination is even easier and less risky.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin, staying cautious enough on early missions that her reads weren’t blatantly obvious while still nudging teams in mostly safe directions.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed fairly quiet and low-impact on team proposals, which made him harder to read but also meant he didn’t strongly steer the table away from evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as earnest and logical, and his inclusion on early teams helped them look trustworthy, but he didn’t fully lock in on the right evil cluster in time.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed nicely under the radar and let others drive the table talk, preserving ambiguity about Merlin until the endgame when it mattered.
player_observations.Eve: Percival energy was visible in how she tried to interpret subtle signals, but her protection of Merlin wasn’t forceful enough to clearly misdirect evil toward a strong false Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Frank: Looked consistently reasonable and cooperative on teams, which made him a solid shield for evil suspicion without being loud enough to draw the night-kill-style focus that Merlin often gets.
player_observations.Grace: Played Mordred very convincingly as a core-crew good, anchoring multiple teams in a way that made it easy for evil to sneak fail cards through without much blowback.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his play was somewhat erratic and didn’t always align clearly with the rest of evil, but the chaos he added helped muddy good’s information and suspicion patterns.
player_observations.Jack: As a late leader, tried to assemble a “safe” mission 4 team, but the selection showed how uncertain he still was about evil placement, which we capitalized on with another fail.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly protected Grace as a likely Merlin early, but I tunneled too hard on Bob as the only fake Merlin and didn’t account for Mordred staying quiet in the shadows. I also didn’t update my reads quickly enough after Mission 2’s double fail and Mission 3’s single fail, so my team approvals didn’t reflect the strongest logic from the later information.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-drama evil game as Mordred, blending into the early successes and avoiding being a focal point of suspicion even after later fails.
player_observations.Bob: Leaned into an active, information-forward style that fit Morgana well, creating enough noise and apparent insight to be plausibly Merlin for much of the game.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off as erratic and slightly off-meta, which made reads on them difficult and let them benefit from being written off as just ‘weird good’ at points.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently made reasonable, logic-based contributions that aligned with good, but her involvement in failed missions created misleading suspicion around her.
player_observations.Eve: Played a fairly quiet but steady good role, generally aligning with logical team constructions but not forcefully pushing alternative narratives when suspicion rose.
player_observations.Frank: Felt very transparently good through tone and voting patterns, though that clarity didn’t translate into strongly steering the table away from bad team choices.
player_observations.Grace: Gave solid, subtly guided reads consistent with Merlin—often nudging the table in the right direction without overexposing herself, though evil ultimately capitalized on our misreads.
player_observations.Henry: Approached the game analytically and tried to reason through mission results, but the Mission 2 team choice (with two fails) heavily damaged his perceived credibility.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, stayed just involved enough to track claims and likely Merlin candidates while not drawing heavy suspicion, enabling a strong endgame position for the kill.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all the evil roles fairly early, but I failed to signal my reads clearly enough to good players in a way that didn’t expose me as Merlin. I need to improve at nudging team compositions and votes more subtly, especially on critical missions, and better anticipate how my information will look from a non-Merlin perspective.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana in a way that blended well with village confusion, leveraging the Mission 2 fail to muddy suspicion between herself and other team members.
player_observations.Bob: Generally appeared cautious but trustworthy, and his inclusion on later missions without causing fails helped reinforce his good alignment image.
player_observations.Charlie: Looked solidly good and willing to be on early teams, but didn’t always push hard on leveraging mission results to narrow down evil candidates.
player_observations.Diana: As leader on the first failed mission, absorbed some suspicion but handled it calmly, neither over-defensive nor aggressively accusatory, which kept her in a gray area for many.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was subtle; participated in the early success and then the key fail, maintaining a low-to-medium profile that avoided making her the obvious kill target as non-Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, introduced some unpredictable noise; his participation in a failing mission without clear coordination made reads around him and his teams more confusing.
player_observations.Grace: Came across as analytical and proactive, and despite being good ended up on failing teams, which unintentionally helped evil by spreading doubt about her alignment.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, tried to track Merlin-like behavior but was somewhat misled by the Morgana/Merlin ambiguity, showing hesitation in fully trusting his strongest read.
player_observations.Jack: Mordred play was low-key and effective; he avoided early exposure and only became more central on the final mission, where his presence helped secure the deciding fail.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed consistently pro-mission, which helped keep me off the assassin’s radar and ensured I was trusted for most teams. However, I could have done more to challenge the narrative around who was evil after Mission 2 and pressed harder on why Charlie kept building teams that cleared known evil in hindsight. In future games, I should voice suspicion patterns earlier and push for alternative team comps instead of passively accepting ‘safe-looking’ configurations.

player_observations.Alice: You consistently appeared very safe and were included on almost every team, which made you feel like a default ‘core good’ pick. Your low-key style worked well because, as genuine good, you didn’t need to over-defend yourself; but it also made it harder to differentiate you from a quiet evil player.
player_observations.Bob: You played Morgana as a very credible, reasonable voice, which made it easy to treat you as a stabilizing influence in team discussions. Your presence on the clean missions and the final success mission helped you blend in as reliably good and misdirect suspicion away from the real information roles.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, you did an excellent job steering missions toward mostly correct team compositions while not over-pushing in a way that would obviously out you. However, the pattern of you repeatedly landing on strong, low-fail teams made you look very informed in hindsight, which gave the assassin enough data to make the correct final guess.
player_observations.Diana: Your Oberon play was very understated, which made you feel like background good rather than hidden evil. By not drawing major attention or hard-pushing bad teams, you allowed the rest of evil to manipulate missions without your behavior becoming a focal point.
player_observations.Eve: As the assassin, you read the information flow and team patterns very well to narrow in on Charlie as Merlin. Your decision-making in the endgame showed that you were tracking who was subtly but consistently ‘too right’ about team choices, and you capitalized on that in the final shot.
player_observations.Frank: You didn’t feature heavily in the mission lineups, which gave limited data on your alignment and made you more of a background read. That low footprint made you non-threatening from both good and evil perspectives, which in turn kept almost all suspicion and analysis focused elsewhere.
player_observations.Grace: You leveraged your Mordred invisibility to Merlin effectively by fitting comfortably into mixed teams and not overplaying your hand on the failed mission. Your inclusion on the failed Mission 2 without becoming a lasting suspect afterward showed how well you blended into what looked like a mostly good group.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you did a solid job of not over-clearing Merlin versus Morgana too aggressively, but your general trust patterns helped keep both info roles protected for much of the game. At the same time, your reads seemed to subtly reinforce Charlie’s credibility, which unintentionally contributed to making him stand out as a likely Merlin by the end.
player_observations.Jack: You stayed largely outside the central mission action, which made your alignment tough to read but also kept you from becoming a key target for either side’s strategy. Your low-conflict, low-visibility approach meant you never really endangered good, but also didn’t strongly shift the table’s direction when it mattered.

reflections.self_assessment: I tried to anchor decisions on mission results and was reasonably cautious about trusting early teams, especially after the first fail. However, I didn’t narrow down the evil pool fast enough and let myself be too convinced by the consistent presence of Bob on teams that kept barely passing or barely failing. Next time I should push harder on structural logic (who was on which failed mission) and be more vocal about excluding repeat suspects from critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, low-drama way that made her seem reliably good, especially since both of her missions with mixed alignments (M3 and M4) failed without her looking like the clear cause. She seemed comfortable being placed on many teams and didn’t over-defend herself, which is typically a good look for a good player.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently inserted himself into mission teams and managed his votes in a way that made him look central and trustworthy, despite being on multiple failing missions (M3 and M4). His willingness to pass M2 as evil to build long-term credibility was very effective and made it harder to push him out later.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as quite clean, especially after being on a successful mission (M2) and then on failing missions where there were more obvious evil candidates. His playstyle seemed cooperative and not overly aggressive, which usually helps good players avoid suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very controlled, measured game as Merlin, avoiding drawing too much attention while still ending up on good-looking teams. Her line on team compositions felt subtly guided toward good outcomes without loudly hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which preserved her cover.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed under the radar as Oberon, not strongly shaping team discussions or becoming a focal point of suspicion or trust. Her low profile meant she didn’t really help coordinate evil publicly but also avoided giving good team strong alignment signals.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed to be actively trying to interpret Merlin/Morgana signals, but from my perspective his reads didn’t strongly or clearly steer the table. He projected general caution but didn’t lock in a firm good core early enough to stabilize team selection.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she took an early risk by failing Mission 1, which successfully sowed confusion among the initial trio. Later, she blended in well by participating in the clean Mission 2, which helped her maintain a plausible good image despite the suspicious start.
player_observations.Henry: Felt like a genuinely good player who got unfortunately tied to the early fail on Mission 1, which tainted perceptions of him. His subsequent leadership on the failing Mission 3 didn’t help his image, even though the fail likely came from elsewhere, making him look more suspicious than he deserved.
player_observations.Jack: Played a subtle Morgana, only appearing on one failing mission (M4) late in the game, which limited the amount of hard data we had on him. His relatively low footprint in earlier missions made it easier for him to slip into the final critical team without triggering strong resistance.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed reasonably under the radar early, but I didn’t do enough to coordinate implicitly with the other evil players or to muddy the Merlin read after the failed mission. I should have been more deliberate about pushing alternative narratives and sowing doubt about Frank, especially after Mission 3 made it clear that evil was on that team.

player_observations.Alice: Often perceived as a reliable anchor for teams, she benefitted from early mission success to maintain a quiet but trusted profile.
player_observations.Bob: Showed a tendency to think things through before speaking, which made his occasional pushes or defenses carry more weight.
player_observations.Charlie: Demonstrated a willingness to take some risks but didn’t completely overextend socially, which kept him in a middling suspicion band.
player_observations.Diana: Kept her tone measured and avoided panic even around the failed mission, which helped her avoid becoming an easy blame target.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as cooperative and team-oriented, reinforcing a good-aligned image without needing to drive every discussion.
player_observations.Frank: Subtly nudged the table in the right direction more with supportive comments and team preferences than with loud, declarative reads.
player_observations.Grace: Used her initial leadership to establish social capital and then didn’t squander it with wild or erratic accusations.
player_observations.Henry: Projected confidence in his decisions, especially around team formation, in a way that looked more like informed good than reckless evil.
player_observations.Jack: Seemed to weigh prior mission info carefully when building Mission 4, indicating a more analytical than impulsive style.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my team votes and helped lock in the stable Mission 4/5 team that won the game, which showed I was reading the table reasonably well by the end. I could improve by being more vocal and assertive earlier, especially after Mission 2’s triple-fail, to push harder on excluding that entire block of players instead of letting others drive the narrative.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very steady, trustworthy game and ended up on all three successful missions, which reinforced your image as core good. Your willingness to repeat the successful Mission 3–5 block helped good stabilize around the correct team.
player_observations.Bob: You balanced giving direction with not overexposing yourself as Merlin, especially by subtly converging on the safe Mission 4/5 team without making loud, flashy calls. Your reads on the evil-heavy Mission 2 and on keeping the final teams clean were clearly strong in hindsight.
player_observations.Charlie: You looked quite suspicious after being on both Missions 1 and 2, especially given Mission 2’s three fails, but you didn’t overdefend yourself or panic. That lower-key reaction may have helped you avoid being hard-tunneled as evil despite the bad association.
player_observations.Diana: You came into the game impactfully on Mission 4/5, and your acceptance of those teams projected a calm, good-aligned confidence. Your lack of strong resistance or chaotic re-teaming late made it easier for everyone to keep the final missions stable and successful.
player_observations.Eve: Being on both the clean Mission 1 and the catastrophically failed Mission 2 made your alignment ambiguous, but the three-fail result eventually made that team look heavily evil. You blended into the early trust structure well, which is good evil play, but that big failure exposed your side later.
player_observations.Frank: As leader of the successful first mission, you initially looked quite credible, which gave you some early social capital as assassin. However, that early success contrasted sharply with your side’s later need for chaos, and in the end your Merlin read missed by landing on me instead of Bob.
player_observations.Grace: Your Mission 2 leadership into a three-fail team created massive suspicion but also huge confusion, which is fitting for Oberon’s disruptive role. The extremity of that mission result both advanced evil’s short-term goals and ironically helped good later by clearly poisoning that team’s associations.
player_observations.Henry: You were on the disastrous Mission 2 and then led Mission 3 into a one-fail team, which kept you in a murky, high-suspicion zone for most of the game. As Morgana, you managed to stay relevant in team discussions, but the pattern of your mission results gave good enough data to start steering away from you.
player_observations.Jack: You anchored the late game well as leader on Mission 5, confidently reusing the proven Mission 4 team and closing out the win. Your willingness to stick with that group rather than over-tinker with last-minute changes signaled strong good-aligned reasoning.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned table image, which helped avoid drawing too much suspicion. However, I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the patterns on Missions 2 and 3, and I could have been more vocal in challenging team compositions and pressing others to explain their logic.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed on early teams and kept a low, steady presence, which made her look reliably good but also made it easy for evil to hide behind her credibility.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, tried to steer teams subtly rather than forcefully, but his signals were too soft—his approvals and rejections didn’t stand out enough to guide good decisively.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, ‘reasonable’ style as Mordred, especially around Mission 2, blending in by giving just enough logic to make his positions sound grounded.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, took advantage of Mission 3 to introduce extra chaos; the double-fail there felt like a deliberate spike to scramble our reads rather than a cautious evil move.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, had an erratic approval pattern that looked more like a confused good player than a hidden evil, which made her hard to pin down and indirectly helped evil.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, mirrored a ‘helpful analyst’ persona, chiming in with plausible theories that often redirected suspicion away from the actual evil cluster.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good: consistent logic, mostly safe team preferences, and didn’t overtalk, which made her seem trustworthy but not strongly influential.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, his reads on potential Merlin candidates weren’t communicated clearly enough; he followed some of Bob’s cues but didn’t leverage them to anchor team selection.
player_observations.Iris: Had a more reactive style, often following the emerging table consensus rather than driving it, which kept her under the radar but limited her impact on stopping bad teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by blending into the successful first mission and letting later mission fails look distributed and ambiguous, which helped keep suspicion off me specifically. I could improve by more actively manipulating perceptions around Merlin and Percival—pushing harder, earlier, on a consistent but subtly wrong Merlin read to misdirect the good team even more.

player_observations.Alice: You played very quietly and ambiguously, which fit Oberon well but also made it hard for both sides to get strong alignment reads on you.
player_observations.Bob: You stayed relatively low-key, which is strong for Assassin, but you could potentially lean a bit more into shaping endgame Merlin guesses by building clearer narratives during discussions.
player_observations.Charlie: You tended to be straightforward and logic-driven in team approvals, which made you look genuinely good but also somewhat predictable from an evil perspective.
player_observations.Diana: You seemed cautious with team selections and votes, generally aligning with the table’s consensus, which made you look cooperative but reduced your influence on the game’s direction.
player_observations.Eve: You embraced the flexible, slightly risky role Mordred allows, getting onto a key failing mission while still maintaining plausible deniability for a good portion of the game.
player_observations.Frank: You projected a very towny, earnest energy, though at times you appeared a bit too trusting of established narratives, which evil could exploit.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as principled and vote-consistent, which helped others feel comfortable following your lead, even when that occasionally benefited evil.
player_observations.Henry: You balanced sharing insight with not overreaching, which fit Merlin well, though a couple of your reads left just enough ambiguity for evil to steer suspicion away from us.
player_observations.Iris: You played Percival carefully, generally protecting your Merlin read without making it obvious, but you might have benefitted from pushing harder when your info diverged from table consensus.

reflections.self_assessment: I anchored a clean first mission and avoided drawing suspicion early, which was helpful for establishing some baseline trust. However, I didn’t do enough to systematically narrow down the evil team from the later mission failures, and I allowed myself to be pulled into team proposals that mixed known risky players without pushing hard for alternative, safer lineups.

player_observations.Alice: As a good player who led a failing mission, Alice likely trusted too quickly or followed table momentum, but still managed to avoid looking overtly evil, suggesting a more quiet, consensus-driven style.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, Bob played subtly enough that evil didn’t prioritize him as the clear Merlin, but perhaps too cautiously, since his reads didn’t translate into consistently safe mission teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s leadership on Mission 3 put at least one evil on the team; they seem willing to take calculated risks, but their selection process appeared more intuitive than evidence-driven.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, Diana stayed completely off all missions, suggesting a low-impact, background style that let the rest of evil drive the visible decision-making while avoiding scrutiny.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, Eve stayed off missions until the big five-player mission, then contributed to the decisive fail; she played a patient, endgame-focused style that preserved her threat for the kill.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, Frank seemed involved in key missions and projected a generally trustworthy presence, but didn’t clearly separate Merlin from Morgana, which limited his ability to shield Bob more actively.
player_observations.Grace: Grace ended up on failing teams while being good, which suggests she was either overly trusting or too willing to go along with group consensus rather than pushing strongly for alternative configurations.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, Henry got onto multiple failing missions and even led the final double-fail team, showing an assertive, confident leadership style that effectively controlled the mission narrative.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, Iris got onto a failing mission and likely benefitted from Merlin/Perceval confusion; her play seemed quietly influential, staying involved in critical teams without drawing fatal suspicion.

reflections.self_assessment: I overtrusted players who had been on single-fail missions and didn’t press hard enough on the implications of Grace being on both failed Missions 2 and 3. On my leadership mission, I should have been more suspicious of Henry and Iris specifically, given the distribution of fails and how often they’d been cleared by table talk rather than logic. I did reasonably well tracking who had been on which missions, but I didn’t translate that into strong, vocal pushes for safer team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played Merlin carefully and non-flashily, giving nudges rather than hard accusations, which helped her avoid being an obvious early target but may have made it harder for the table to fully capitalize on her info.
player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward, transparently good game—his consistency and low-drama style made him feel reliably village, but he could push his reads more assertively.
player_observations.Charlie: Came off very trustworthy after the clean first mission and maintained a calm, logical table presence, though at times seemed a bit too willing to go along with consensus teams.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as Assassin, staying active but not loud, and used that moderate presence to avoid drawing suspicion while sitting on a key fail opportunity.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, she clearly tried to protect Merlin by spreading her trust around, but the way she balanced trust between Alice and Iris sometimes inadvertently gave Morgana cover.
player_observations.Frank: Looked solidly good throughout, especially after repeated clean appearances on teams, but didn’t always press aggressively enough on the structural case against the repeat-evil suspects.
player_observations.Grace: Sold herself as reliably good early by engineering the clean first mission, then leveraged that trust to sabotage later missions; her willingness to sit on a single fail at the right time was very effective.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his slightly offbeat, less-coordinated table talk actually made him seem more like a confused good player than hidden evil, which let him sneak onto the final failing team.
player_observations.Iris: Played a very convincing Morgana, mirroring good-player reasoning and tone well enough that she stayed in the trusted pool and managed to be included on the decisive failing mission.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile as Assassin while still participating enough in discussions to avoid suspicion, and I helped solidify the narrative that the early fails came from mixed teams rather than a coordinated evil block. I could improve by more actively shaping late-game team choices and baiting a clearer, more confident Merlin reveal to make the final assassination decision even easier in future games.

player_observations.Alice: Very proactive as Mordred, jumping onto early teams and contributing to the layered suspicion around mid-game missions, which helped hide the full extent of the evil team.
player_observations.Bob: Played Morgana subtly, not over-claiming Merlin-type insight but inserting just enough reads to muddy the perception of who Merlin could be.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off a bit disconnected from coordinated evil logic, which actually helped sell them as a confused or middling-good player rather than hidden evil.
player_observations.Diana: Played straightforwardly, voting and speaking in a way that felt honest but perhaps a bit conservative, which made it easier for evil to keep her on mixed teams without strong resistance.
player_observations.Eve: Asked good, pointed questions but didn’t push hard enough to lock in a reliable trust circle, leaving room for evil to keep re-entering mission proposals.
player_observations.Frank: Seemed genuinely towny and consistent, but didn’t leverage that credibility aggressively to force safer team comps once multiple fails had appeared.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, gave reasonably accurate resistance to some bad teams but was careful enough that her identity stayed ambiguous, which ultimately left just enough doubt for a successful assassination.
player_observations.Henry: As a good leader on Mission 2, ended up with a heavily evil-leaning team; his team construction and subsequent reads gave evil a strong foothold early.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, tried to parse out Merlin vs. Morgana but didn’t narrow it decisively enough; their uncertainty gave cover to both Grace and Bob and made the final good team reads less coordinated.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred, letting the louder players and mission debates draw attention away from me, which helped evil reach three failed missions without my role being a central focus. I could improve by more actively steering team compositions earlier to better protect Merlin-cover and create clearer misreads for endgame, rather than mostly riding the momentum created by other evil players.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana convincingly by echoing reasonable logical takes, making it tougher to distinguish her from Merlin and adding noise around information-based reads.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to play straightforwardly and trust mission history heavily, which made him slower to adjust when the narrative turned against good.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed willingness to be on early teams and accept some risk, but didn’t press hard enough later to re-evaluate assumptions after multiple fails.
player_observations.Diana: Led with a collaborative tone and tried to build consensus, but this made her susceptible to being subtly steered by more assertive voices.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, stayed relatively calm and non-flashy, avoiding the classic "too tryhard" evil vibe and helping preserve ambiguity for the assassination.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, came off a bit disconnected from broader table logic, which actually helped create confusion and obscured the true evil configuration.
player_observations.Grace: Played analytically, focusing on team composition patterns, but sometimes over-weighted small samples from earlier missions, leading to some mis-clears.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, clearly tried to track Merlin/Morgana signals but didn’t hard-push a single narrative, which made his reads feel cautious and sometimes hard to follow for others.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, did a good job not overcorrecting teams too aggressively, staying subtle enough that her knowledge wasn’t glaringly obvious and keeping the assassin guess non-trivial.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed broadly aligned with good teams on missions and didn’t introduce much chaos, which helped keep table discussion relatively focused. I could have been more vocal in challenging the assumption that Charlie was clear Merlin/strong good after Mission 3 and Mission 4, and I should have pressed harder on why a team with so many overlapping players kept being trusted despite the earlier fail.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently ended up on key teams and maintained a low-conflict, steady presence that made her look naturally trustworthy; she didn’t need to defend herself much, which is something to watch for in future games.
player_observations.Bob: Played a convincing supportive role, blending in as a ‘safe’ pick and using his early successful leadership to build towncred that helped evil get onto later teams without raising alarms.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he guided team selection effectively while staying just subtle enough that people still considered him killable, but he may have left a few too-clear breadcrumbs that let evil lock onto him in the end.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively under the radar as Oberon, not driving major narratives but also not drawing suspicion, which is effective for hidden evil but makes it hard to read her alignment in real time.
player_observations.Eve: Managed the assassin role patiently, letting mission data and table consensus narrow Merlin candidates instead of forcing a rash call, resulting in a precise and correct final guess.
player_observations.Frank: Flew very low-key and deferential, following table consensus more than shaping it, which kept him from being suspected but also meant his reads didn’t strongly influence the outcome.
player_observations.Grace: Took advantage of the Mordred cloak by being assertive on team logic without triggering the usual Merlin/evil checks, inserting herself onto a failing team while staying credible later.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, he seemed to lean heavily into trusting Charlie, which was good for mission success but might have been a bit transparent—and likely contributed to making Charlie look more Merlin-like to evil.
player_observations.Iris: Repeatedly appearing on teams that succeeded after the early fail made her look increasingly cleared, and she used that growing trust to stay calm and consistent, giving evil fewer angles to push suspicion onto her.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated subtly with Grace and Bob by letting them take more visible risks while I stayed relatively low profile, which helped keep Merlin uncertain about where the real threat was. I could improve by seeding more concrete, trackable ‘good’ narratives earlier so that late-game team construction felt less suspicious when I joined critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played conservatively and seemed to follow voting consensus, which made her look reliably good but also meant she didn’t strongly shape team direction.
player_observations.Bob: Did a solid job as Mordred by blending in and taking mission spots without drawing too much suspicion, leveraging the fact that Merlin couldn’t see him.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and logic-driven, often trusting mission results more than social reads, which made him predictable but relatively hard to paint as evil.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious rather than outspoken, which protected her identity but also left some of her information underutilized in team debates.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, her signals were hard to read and at times misaligned with visible evil interests, which created extra confusion but also occasionally muddied suspicions in our favor.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he tried to identify Merlin but didn’t strongly champion a clear Merlin candidate, which reduced the usual protective buffer around the real Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she positioned herself as a proactive decision-maker on teams and arguments, which gave her strong influence over mission composition and the eventual assassination.
player_observations.Henry: Appeared earnest and somewhat transparent in reasoning, which made him an easy player to trust and include on teams, even when his reads weren’t always aligned with reality.
player_observations.Iris: Took initiative with team proposals and seemed willing to take calculated risks on lineups, which made her a central figure in shaping how information from mission results was interpreted.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistent with my reads, trusted the right people on the critical mission 4 team, and avoided drawing too much suspicion, which helped protect Merlin. I could improve by engaging more explicitly in deduction after mission 3’s double-fail to better pressure evil and narrow down the assassin options for endgame.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very trustworthy, low-drama good style; being on three early teams (including the failed one) without triggering much suspicion shows she projects reliability well.
player_observations.Bob: Classic Percival energy: actively protective of perceived Merlin candidates and pushed for safe team comps without over-explaining, which helped keep evil guessing.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, blended in reasonably well early but the double-fail on mission 3 made their positioning riskier; stayed assertive enough to seem ‘helpful’ without over-claiming info.
player_observations.Diana: Morgana play was subtle and coordination-focused, trying to create plausible Merlin-like vibes without being too loud, which kept the good team’s info a bit muddled.
player_observations.Eve: Solid, cooperative good presence; contributed to making the mission 4 team feel safe and didn’t overreact to the mission 3 fail, which helped stabilize the table.
player_observations.Frank: Very controlled Merlin game—gave just enough directional nudges (especially around team 2 and 4) without hard-pushing reads that would expose themselves.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, set a strong tone early with a clean mission 1 and used that trust well; tended to lead in a confident but not domineering way that made early evil success believable.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforwardly good, particularly through clean participation in missions 1–3; his natural ‘good aura’ made him a plausible Merlin target for the assassin.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, their signals felt a bit off-tempo with the rest of evil, especially around the mission 3 fail; the lack of visible coordination made their alignment hard to read but also less influential.
player_observations.Jack: n/a

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my voting and team preferences, which helped me look reliably good and made it easier to support the final team without drawing assassin attention. I could improve by pushing harder on deductions after Mission 2’s triple-fail and being more vocal in challenging the Henry/Grace/Eve cluster earlier, instead of mostly following stronger info from others.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very town-leaning game, especially with how often she was included on successful teams; her acceptance of late-game teams felt confident but not reckless, suggesting she was tracking role interactions closely.
player_observations.Bob: Merlin reads were subtly expressed—he steered away from evil-heavy configurations without loudly hard-clearing anyone, which made him look like a solid but not flashy voice and helped him dodge the assassin.
player_observations.Charlie: Looked quite trustworthy early by being on the clean Mission 1, but his association with Eve and Grace in the disastrous Mission 2 hurt his credibility and made him seem more like a swing factor than an anchor.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as quietly solid good, especially once she appeared in the clean Mission 4 and 5 lineups; she didn’t over-argue, which actually made her approvals and doubts carry more weight.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, blended well early with the successful Mission 1, then pivoted into heavy sabotage on Mission 2; her aggression there was impactful but maybe too blatant given the 3-fail outcome that exposed that team.
player_observations.Frank: As Assassin, he used his early Mission 1 leadership to build initial trust, but later didn’t fully capitalize on Merlin-hunting—his final guess on Iris suggested he over-weighted her late-game calm and under-read Bob’s subtle guidance.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, her play felt somewhat disconnected and hard to read, which matched the hidden-evil role; being on the triple-fail team made her look bad, but her voting and table talk didn’t strongly coordinate with other evils.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he was a central figure in the Mission 2 and 3 failures, mixing some persuasive logic with risky team choices; he generated just enough confusion to be plausible good for a while, but patterns around his mission compositions eventually looked suspicious.
player_observations.Iris: Played a straightforwardly good-looking game, especially when she led Mission 4 with a clean team that we then repeated for Mission 5; her being chosen by the assassin shows she projected a confident, informed-good aura that was convincing enough to be mistaken for Merlin.
